      77             : /* ----------
      78             :  * Pretty formatting constants
      79             :  * ----------
      80             :  */
      81             : 
      82             : /* Indent counts */
      83             : #define PRETTYINDENT_STD        8
      84             : #define PRETTYINDENT_JOIN       4
      85             : #define PRETTYINDENT_VAR        4
      86             : 
      87             : #define PRETTYINDENT_LIMIT      40  /* wrap limit */
      88             : 
      89             : /* Pretty flags */
      90             : #define PRETTYFLAG_PAREN        0x0001
      91             : #define PRETTYFLAG_INDENT       0x0002
      92             : #define PRETTYFLAG_SCHEMA       0x0004
      93             : 
      94             : /* Default line length for pretty-print wrapping: 0 means wrap always */
      95             : #define WRAP_COLUMN_DEFAULT     0
      96             : 
      97             : /* macros to test if pretty action needed */
      98             : #define PRETTY_PAREN(context)   ((context)->prettyFlags & PRETTYFLAG_PAREN)
      99             : #define PRETTY_INDENT(context)  ((context)->prettyFlags & PRETTYFLAG_INDENT)
     100             : #define PRETTY_SCHEMA(context)  ((context)->prettyFlags & PRETTYFLAG_SCHEMA)
     101             : 
     102             : 
     103             : /* ----------
     104             :  * Local data types
     105             :  * ----------
     106             :  */
     107             : 
     108             : /* Context info needed for invoking a recursive querytree display routine */
     109             : typedef struct
     110             : {
     111             :     StringInfo  buf;            /* output buffer to append to */
     112             :     List       *namespaces;     /* List of deparse_namespace nodes */
     113             :     List       *windowClause;   /* Current query level's WINDOW clause */
     114             :     List       *windowTList;    /* targetlist for resolving WINDOW clause */
     115             :     int         prettyFlags;    /* enabling of pretty-print functions */
     116             :     int         wrapColumn;     /* max line length, or -1 for no limit */
     117             :     int         indentLevel;    /* current indent level for pretty-print */
     118             :     bool        varprefix;      /* true to print prefixes on Vars */
     119             :     ParseExprKind special_exprkind; /* set only for exprkinds needing special
     120             :                                      * handling */
     121             : } deparse_context;
     122             : 
     123             : /*
     124             :  * Each level of query context around a subtree needs a level of Var namespace.
     125             :  * A Var having varlevelsup=N refers to the N'th item (counting from 0) in
     126             :  * the current context's namespaces list.
     127             :  *
     128             :  * The rangetable is the list of actual RTEs from the query tree, and the
     129             :  * cte list is the list of actual CTEs.
     130             :  *
     131             :  * rtable_names holds the alias name to be used for each RTE (either a C
     132             :  * string, or NULL for nameless RTEs such as unnamed joins).
     133             :  * rtable_columns holds the column alias names to be used for each RTE.
     134             :  *
     135             :  * In some cases we need to make names of merged JOIN USING columns unique
     136             :  * across the whole query, not only per-RTE.  If so, unique_using is true
     137             :  * and using_names is a list of C strings representing names already assigned
     138             :  * to USING columns.
     139             :  *
     140             :  * When deparsing plan trees, there is always just a single item in the
     141             :  * deparse_namespace list (since a plan tree never contains Vars with
     142             :  * varlevelsup > 0).  We store the PlanState node that is the immediate
     143             :  * parent of the expression to be deparsed, as well as a list of that
     144             :  * PlanState's ancestors.  In addition, we store its outer and inner subplan
     145             :  * state nodes, as well as their plan nodes' targetlists, and the index tlist
     146             :  * if the current plan node might contain INDEX_VAR Vars.  (These fields could
     147             :  * be derived on-the-fly from the current PlanState, but it seems notationally
     148             :  * clearer to set them up as separate fields.)
     149             :  */
     150             : typedef struct
     151             : {
     152             :     List       *rtable;         /* List of RangeTblEntry nodes */
     153             :     List       *rtable_names;   /* Parallel list of names for RTEs */
     154             :     List       *rtable_columns; /* Parallel list of deparse_columns structs */
     155             :     List       *ctes;           /* List of CommonTableExpr nodes */
     156             :     /* Workspace for column alias assignment: */
     157             :     bool        unique_using;   /* Are we making USING names globally unique */
     158             :     List       *using_names;    /* List of assigned names for USING columns */
     159             :     /* Remaining fields are used only when deparsing a Plan tree: */
     160             :     PlanState  *planstate;      /* immediate parent of current expression */
     161             :     List       *ancestors;      /* ancestors of planstate */
     162             :     PlanState  *outer_planstate;    /* outer subplan state, or NULL if none */
     163             :     PlanState  *inner_planstate;    /* inner subplan state, or NULL if none */
     164             :     List       *outer_tlist;    /* referent for OUTER_VAR Vars */
     165             :     List       *inner_tlist;    /* referent for INNER_VAR Vars */
     166             :     List       *index_tlist;    /* referent for INDEX_VAR Vars */
     167             : } deparse_namespace;
     168             : 
     169             : /*
     170             :  * Per-relation data about column alias names.
     171             :  *
     172             :  * Selecting aliases is unreasonably complicated because of the need to dump
     173             :  * rules/views whose underlying tables may have had columns added, deleted, or
     174             :  * renamed since the query was parsed.  We must nonetheless print the rule/view
     175             :  * in a form that can be reloaded and will produce the same results as before.
     176             :  *
     177             :  * For each RTE used in the query, we must assign column aliases that are
     178             :  * unique within that RTE.  SQL does not require this of the original query,
     179             :  * but due to factors such as *-expansion we need to be able to uniquely
     180             :  * reference every column in a decompiled query.  As long as we qualify all
     181             :  * column references, per-RTE uniqueness is sufficient for that.
     182             :  *
     183             :  * However, we can't ensure per-column name uniqueness for unnamed join RTEs,
     184             :  * since they just inherit column names from their input RTEs, and we can't
     185             :  * rename the columns at the join level.  Most of the time this isn't an issue
     186             :  * because we don't need to reference the join's output columns as such; we
     187             :  * can reference the input columns instead.  That approach can fail for merged
     188             :  * JOIN USING columns, however, so when we have one of those in an unnamed
     189             :  * join, we have to make that column's alias globally unique across the whole
     190             :  * query to ensure it can be referenced unambiguously.
     191             :  *
     192             :  * Another problem is that a JOIN USING clause requires the columns to be
     193             :  * merged to have the same aliases in both input RTEs, and that no other
     194             :  * columns in those RTEs or their children conflict with the USING names.
     195             :  * To handle that, we do USING-column alias assignment in a recursive
     196             :  * traversal of the query's jointree.  When descending through a JOIN with
     197             :  * USING, we preassign the USING column names to the child columns, overriding
     198             :  * other rules for column alias assignment.  We also mark each RTE with a list
     199             :  * of all USING column names selected for joins containing that RTE, so that
     200             :  * when we assign other columns' aliases later, we can avoid conflicts.
     201             :  *
     202             :  * Another problem is that if a JOIN's input tables have had columns added or
     203             :  * deleted since the query was parsed, we must generate a column alias list
     204             :  * for the join that matches the current set of input columns --- otherwise, a
     205             :  * change in the number of columns in the left input would throw off matching
     206             :  * of aliases to columns of the right input.  Thus, positions in the printable
     207             :  * column alias list are not necessarily one-for-one with varattnos of the
     208             :  * JOIN, so we need a separate new_colnames[] array for printing purposes.
     209             :  */
     210             : typedef struct
     211             : {
     212             :     /*
     213             :      * colnames is an array containing column aliases to use for columns that
     214             :      * existed when the query was parsed.  Dropped columns have NULL entries.
     215             :      * This array can be directly indexed by varattno to get a Var's name.
     216             :      *
     217             :      * Non-NULL entries are guaranteed unique within the RTE, *except* when
     218             :      * this is for an unnamed JOIN RTE.  In that case we merely copy up names
     219             :      * from the two input RTEs.
     220             :      *
     221             :      * During the recursive descent in set_using_names(), forcible assignment
     222             :      * of a child RTE's column name is represented by pre-setting that element
     223             :      * of the child's colnames array.  So at that stage, NULL entries in this
     224             :      * array just mean that no name has been preassigned, not necessarily that
     225             :      * the column is dropped.
     226             :      */
     227             :     int         num_cols;       /* length of colnames[] array */
     228             :     char      **colnames;       /* array of C strings and NULLs */
     229             : 
     230             :     /*
     231             :      * new_colnames is an array containing column aliases to use for columns
     232             :      * that would exist if the query was re-parsed against the current
     233             :      * definitions of its base tables.  This is what to print as the column
     234             :      * alias list for the RTE.  This array does not include dropped columns,
     235             :      * but it will include columns added since original parsing.  Indexes in
     236             :      * it therefore have little to do with current varattno values.  As above,
     237             :      * entries are unique unless this is for an unnamed JOIN RTE.  (In such an
     238             :      * RTE, we never actually print this array, but we must compute it anyway
     239             :      * for possible use in computing column names of upper joins.) The
     240             :      * parallel array is_new_col marks which of these columns are new since
     241             :      * original parsing.  Entries with is_new_col false must match the
     242             :      * non-NULL colnames entries one-for-one.
     243             :      */
     244             :     int         num_new_cols;   /* length of new_colnames[] array */
     245             :     char      **new_colnames;   /* array of C strings */
     246             :     bool       *is_new_col;     /* array of bool flags */
     247             : 
     248             :     /* This flag tells whether we should actually print a column alias list */
     249             :     bool        printaliases;
     250             : 
     251             :     /* This list has all names used as USING names in joins above this RTE */
     252             :     List       *parentUsing;    /* names assigned to parent merged columns */
     253             : 
     254             :     /*
     255             :      * If this struct is for a JOIN RTE, we fill these fields during the
     256             :      * set_using_names() pass to describe its relationship to its child RTEs.
     257             :      *
     258             :      * leftattnos and rightattnos are arrays with one entry per existing
     259             :      * output column of the join (hence, indexable by join varattno).  For a
     260             :      * simple reference to a column of the left child, leftattnos[i] is the
     261             :      * child RTE's attno and rightattnos[i] is zero; and conversely for a
     262             :      * column of the right child.  But for merged columns produced by JOIN
     263             :      * USING/NATURAL JOIN, both leftattnos[i] and rightattnos[i] are nonzero.
     264             :      * Also, if the column has been dropped, both are zero.
     265             :      *
     266             :      * If it's a JOIN USING, usingNames holds the alias names selected for the
     267             :      * merged columns (these might be different from the original USING list,
     268             :      * if we had to modify names to achieve uniqueness).
     269             :      */
     270             :     int         leftrti;        /* rangetable index of left child */
     271             :     int         rightrti;       /* rangetable index of right child */
     272             :     int        *leftattnos;     /* left-child varattnos of join cols, or 0 */
     273             :     int        *rightattnos;    /* right-child varattnos of join cols, or 0 */
     274             :     List       *usingNames;     /* names assigned to merged columns */
     275             : } deparse_columns;
     276             : 
     277             : /* This macro is analogous to rt_fetch(), but for deparse_columns structs */
     278             : #define deparse_columns_fetch(rangetable_index, dpns) \
     279             :     ((deparse_columns *) list_nth((dpns)->rtable_columns, (rangetable_index)-1))
     280             : 
     281             : /*
     282             :  * Entry in set_rtable_names' hash table
     283             :  */
     284             : typedef struct
     285             : {
     286             :     char        name[NAMEDATALEN];  /* Hash key --- must be first */
     287             :     int         counter;        /* Largest addition used so far for name */
     288             : } NameHashEntry;
     289             : 
     290             :

     292             :  * Global data
     293             :  * ----------
     294             :  */
     295             : static SPIPlanPtr plan_getrulebyoid = NULL;
     296             : static const char *query_getrulebyoid = "SELECT * FROM pg_catalog.pg_rewrite WHERE oid = $1";
     297             : static SPIPlanPtr plan_getviewrule = NULL;
     298             : static const char *query_getviewrule = "SELECT * FROM pg_catalog.pg_rewrite WHERE ev_class = $1 AND rulename = $2";
     299             : 
     300             : /* GUC parameters */
     301             : bool        quote_all_identifiers = false;

     306             :  *
     307             :  * Most of these functions used to use fixed-size buffers to build their
     308             :  * results.  Now, they take an (already initialized) StringInfo object
     309             :  * as a parameter, and append their text output to its contents.

    1082             : 
    1083             : /* ----------
    1084             :  * pg_get_indexdef          - Get the definition of an index
    1085             :  *
    1086             :  * In the extended version, there is a colno argument as well as pretty bool.
    1087             :  *  if colno == 0, we want a complete index definition.
    1088             :  *  if colno > 0, we only want the Nth index key's variable or expression.
    1089             :  *
    1090             :  * Note that the SQL-function versions of this omit any info about the
    1091             :  * index tablespace; this is intentional because pg_dump wants it that way.
    1092             :  * However pg_get_indexdef_string() includes the index tablespace.
    1093             :  * ----------
    1094             :  */
    1095             : Datum
    1096         148 : pg_get_indexdef(PG_FUNCTION_ARGS)
    1097             : {
    1098         148 :     Oid         indexrelid = PG_GETARG_OID(0);
    1099             :     int         prettyFlags;
    1100             :     char       *res;
    1101             : 
    1102         148 :     prettyFlags = PRETTYFLAG_INDENT;
    1103             : 
    1104         148 :     res = pg_get_indexdef_worker(indexrelid, 0, NULL,
    1105             :                                  false, false,
    1106             :                                  false, false,
    1107             :                                  prettyFlags, true);
    1108             : 
    1109         148 :     if (res == NULL)
    1110           2 :         PG_RETURN_NULL();
    1111             : 
    1112         146 :     PG_RETURN_TEXT_P(string_to_text(res));
    1113             : }
    1114             : 
    1115             : Datum
    1116         446 : pg_get_indexdef_ext(PG_FUNCTION_ARGS)

    2342             : /* ----------
    2343             :  * pg_get_expr          - Decompile an expression tree
    2344             :  *
    2345             :  * Input: an expression tree in nodeToString form, and a relation OID
    2346             :  *
    2347             :  * Output: reverse-listed expression
    2348             :  *
    2349             :  * Currently, the expression can only refer to a single relation, namely
    2350             :  * the one specified by the second parameter.  This is sufficient for
    2351             :  * partial indexes, column default expressions, etc.  We also support
    2352             :  * Var-free expressions, for which the OID can be InvalidOid.
    2353             :  * ----------
    2354             :  */

    2369             : 
    2370             :         /*
    2371             :          * If the OID isn't actually valid, don't throw an error, just return
    2372             :          * NULL.  This is a bit questionable, but it's what we've done
    2373             :          * historically, and it can help avoid unwanted failures when
    2374             :          * examining catalog entries for just-deleted relations.
    2375             :          */
    2376         432 :         if (relname == NULL)
    2377           0 :             PG_RETURN_NULL();
    2378             :     }
    2379             :     else
    2380           0 :         relname = NULL;

    2476             : /*

    2539             :          */

    2541           8 :             deprec->objsubid == 0 &&

    2547           4 :             break;
    2548             :         }

    2566             : 
    2567             : /*
    2568             :  * pg_get_functiondef
    2569             :  *      Returns the complete "CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION ..." statement for
    2570             :  *      the specified function.
    2571             :  *
    2572             :  * Note: if you change the output format of this function, be careful not
    2573             :  * to break psql's rules (in \ef and \sf) for identifying the start of the
    2574             :  * function body.  To wit: the function body starts on a line that begins
    2575             :  * with "AS ", and no preceding line will look like that.

    2737             :                  * rules used there aren't exactly like SQL's, we have to
    2738             :                  * break the list value apart and then quote the elements as
    2739             :                  * string literals.  (The elements may be double-quoted as-is,
    2740             :                  * but we can't just feed them to the SQL parser; it would do
    2741             :                  * the wrong thing with elements that are zero-length or
    2742             :                  * longer than NAMEDATALEN.)

    2745             :                  * simple string literals.  If the variable is not known to

    2934             : /*
    2935             :  * Common code for pg_get_function_arguments and pg_get_function_result:
    2936             :  * append the desired subset of arguments to buf.  We print only TABLE
    2937             :  * arguments when print_table_args is true, and all the others when it's false.
    2938             :  * We print argument defaults only if print_defaults is true.
    2939             :  * Function return value is the number of arguments printed.
    2940             :  */

    3191             : /*
    3192             :  * deparse_expression           - General utility for deparsing expressions
    3193             :  *

    3197       10582 : deparse_expression(Node *expr, List *dpcontext,
    3198             :                    bool forceprefix, bool showimplicit)
    3199             : {
    3200       10582 :     return deparse_expression_pretty(expr, dpcontext, forceprefix,
    3201             :                                      showimplicit, 0, 0);
    3202             : }
    3203             : 
    3204             : /* ----------
    3205             :  * deparse_expression_pretty    - General utility for deparsing expressions
    3206             :  *
    3207             :  * expr is the node tree to be deparsed.  It must be a transformed expression
    3208             :  * tree (ie, not the raw output of gram.y).
    3209             :  *
    3210             :  * dpcontext is a list of deparse_namespace nodes representing the context
    3211             :  * for interpreting Vars in the node tree.  It can be NIL if no Vars are
    3212             :  * expected.
    3213             :  *
    3214             :  * forceprefix is true to force all Vars to be prefixed with their table names.
    3215             :  *
    3216             :  * showimplicit is true to force all implicit casts to be shown explicitly.
    3217             :  *
    3218             :  * Tries to pretty up the output according to prettyFlags and startIndent.
    3219             :  *
    3220             :  * The result is a palloc'd string.
    3221             :  * ----------
    3222             :  */
    3223             : static char *
    3224       11520 : deparse_expression_pretty(Node *expr, List *dpcontext,
    3225             :                           bool forceprefix, bool showimplicit,
    3226             :                           int prettyFlags, int startIndent)
    3227             : {
    3228             :     StringInfoData buf;
    3229             :     deparse_context context;
    3230             : 
    3231       11520 :     initStringInfo(&buf);
    3232       11520 :     context.buf = &buf;
    3233       11520 :     context.namespaces = dpcontext;
    3234       11520 :     context.windowClause = NIL;
    3235       11520 :     context.windowTList = NIL;
    3236       11520 :     context.varprefix = forceprefix;
    3237       11520 :     context.prettyFlags = prettyFlags;
    3238       11520 :     context.wrapColumn = WRAP_COLUMN_DEFAULT;
    3239       11520 :     context.indentLevel = startIndent;
    3240       11520 :     context.special_exprkind = EXPR_KIND_NONE;
    3241             : 
    3242       11520 :     get_rule_expr(expr, &context, showimplicit);
    3243             : 
    3244       11520 :     return buf.data;
    3245             : }

    3247             : /* ----------
    3248             :  * deparse_context_for          - Build deparse context for a single relation

    3251             :  * context for an expression referencing only that relation (as varno 1,

    3285             : /*
    3286             :  * deparse_context_for_plan_rtable - Build deparse context for a plan's rtable
    3287             :  *
    3288             :  * When deparsing an expression in a Plan tree, we use the plan's rangetable
    3289             :  * to resolve names of simple Vars.  The initialization of column names for
    3290             :  * this is rather expensive if the rangetable is large, and it'll be the same
    3291             :  * for every expression in the Plan tree; so we do it just once and re-use
    3292             :  * the result of this function for each expression.  (Note that the result
    3293             :  * is not usable until set_deparse_context_planstate() is applied to it.)
    3294             :  *
    3295             :  * In addition to the plan's rangetable list, pass the per-RTE alias names
    3296             :  * assigned by a previous call to select_rtable_names_for_explain.
    3297             :  */
    3298             : List *
    3299        3440 : deparse_context_for_plan_rtable(List *rtable, List *rtable_names)
    3300             : {
    3301             :     deparse_namespace *dpns;
    3302             : 
    3303        3440 :     dpns = (deparse_namespace *) palloc0(sizeof(deparse_namespace));
    3304             : 
    3305             :     /* Initialize fields that stay the same across the whole plan tree */
    3306        3440 :     dpns->rtable = rtable;
    3307        3440 :     dpns->rtable_names = rtable_names;
    3308        3440 :     dpns->ctes = NIL;
    3309             : 
    3310             :     /*
    3311             :      * Set up column name aliases.  We will get rather bogus results for join
    3312             :      * RTEs, but that doesn't matter because plan trees don't contain any join
    3313             :      * alias Vars.
    3314             :      */
    3315        3440 :     set_simple_column_names(dpns);
    3316             : 
    3317             :     /* Return a one-deep namespace stack */
    3318        3440 :     return list_make1(dpns);
    3319             : }
    3320             : 
    3321             : /*
    3322             :  * set_deparse_context_planstate    - Specify Plan node containing expression
    3323             :  *
    3324             :  * When deparsing an expression in a Plan tree, we might have to resolve
    3325             :  * OUTER_VAR, INNER_VAR, or INDEX_VAR references.  To do this, the caller must
    3326             :  * provide the parent PlanState node.  Then OUTER_VAR and INNER_VAR references
    3327             :  * can be resolved by drilling down into the left and right child plans.
    3328             :  * Similarly, INDEX_VAR references can be resolved by reference to the
    3329             :  * indextlist given in a parent IndexOnlyScan node, or to the scan tlist in
    3330             :  * ForeignScan and CustomScan nodes.  (Note that we don't currently support
    3331             :  * deparsing of indexquals in regular IndexScan or BitmapIndexScan nodes;
    3332             :  * for those, we can only deparse the indexqualorig fields, which won't
    3333             :  * contain INDEX_VAR Vars.)
    3334             :  *
    3335             :  * Note: planstate really ought to be declared as "PlanState *", but we use
    3336             :  * "Node *" to avoid having to include execnodes.h in ruleutils.h.
    3337             :  *
    3338             :  * The ancestors list is a list of the PlanState's parent PlanStates, the
    3339             :  * most-closely-nested first.  This is needed to resolve PARAM_EXEC Params.
    3340             :  * Note we assume that all the PlanStates share the same rtable.
    3341             :  *
    3342             :  * Once this function has been called, deparse_expression() can be called on
    3343             :  * subsidiary expression(s) of the specified PlanState node.  To deparse
    3344             :  * expressions of a different Plan node in the same Plan tree, re-call this
    3345             :  * function to identify the new parent Plan node.
    3346             :  *
    3347             :  * The result is the same List passed in; this is a notational convenience.
    3348             :  */
    3349             : List *
    3350        8408 : set_deparse_context_planstate(List *dpcontext,
    3351             :                               Node *planstate, List *ancestors)
    3352             : {
    3353             :     deparse_namespace *dpns;
    3354             : 
    3355             :     /* Should always have one-entry namespace list for Plan deparsing */
    3356        8408 :     Assert(list_length(dpcontext) == 1);
    3357        8408 :     dpns = (deparse_namespace *) linitial(dpcontext);
    3358             : 
    3359             :     /* Set our attention on the specific plan node passed in */
    3360        8408 :     set_deparse_planstate(dpns, (PlanState *) planstate);
    3361        8408 :     dpns->ancestors = ancestors;
    3362             : 
    3363        8408 :     return dpcontext;
    3364             : }
    3365             : 
    3366             : /*
    3367             :  * select_rtable_names_for_explain  - Select RTE aliases for EXPLAIN

    3373             : List *
    3374        3440 : select_rtable_names_for_explain(List *rtable, Bitmapset *rels_used)
    3375             : {
    3376             :     deparse_namespace dpns;

    3386             : 
    3387             : /*
    3388             :  * set_rtable_names: select RTE aliases to be used in printing a query
    3389             :  *
    3390             :  * We fill in dpns->rtable_names with a list of names that is one-for-one with
    3391             :  * the already-filled dpns->rtable list.  Each RTE name is unique among those
    3392             :  * in the new namespace plus any ancestor namespaces listed in
    3393             :  * parent_namespaces.
    3394             :  *
    3395             :  * If rels_used isn't NULL, only RTE indexes listed in it are given aliases.
    3396             :  *
    3397             :  * Note that this function is only concerned with relation names, not column
    3398             :  * names.
    3399             :  */
    3400             : static void
    3401        6254 : set_rtable_names(deparse_namespace *dpns, List *parent_namespaces,
    3402             :                  Bitmapset *rels_used)
    3403             : {
    3404             :     HASHCTL     hash_ctl;

    3408             :     int         rtindex;
    3409             :     ListCell   *lc;
    3410             : 
    3411        6254 :     dpns->rtable_names = NIL;

    3413        6254 :     if (dpns->rtable == NIL)
    3414        6266 :         return;
    3415             : 
    3416             :     /*
    3417             :      * We use a hash table to hold known names, so that this process is O(N)

    3423        6242 :     hash_ctl.hcxt = CurrentMemoryContext;

    3425        6242 :                              list_length(dpns->rtable),
    3426             :                              &hash_ctl,

    3544             : /*
    3545             :  * set_deparse_for_query: set up deparse_namespace for deparsing a Query tree
    3546             :  *
    3547             :  * For convenience, this is defined to initialize the deparse_namespace struct
    3548             :  * from scratch.
    3549             :  */
    3550             : static void
    3551         828 : set_deparse_for_query(deparse_namespace *dpns, Query *query,
    3552             :                       List *parent_namespaces)
    3553             : {
    3554             :     ListCell   *lc;
    3555             :     ListCell   *lc2;
    3556             : 
    3557             :     /* Initialize *dpns and fill rtable/ctes links */
    3558         828 :     memset(dpns, 0, sizeof(deparse_namespace));
    3559         828 :     dpns->rtable = query->rtable;
    3560         828 :     dpns->ctes = query->cteList;
    3561             : 
    3562             :     /* Assign a unique relation alias to each RTE */
    3563         828 :     set_rtable_names(dpns, parent_namespaces, NULL);
    3564             : 
    3565             :     /* Initialize dpns->rtable_columns to contain zeroed structs */
    3566         828 :     dpns->rtable_columns = NIL;
    3567        4362 :     while (list_length(dpns->rtable_columns) < list_length(dpns->rtable))
    3568        2706 :         dpns->rtable_columns = lappend(dpns->rtable_columns,
    3569             :                                        palloc0(sizeof(deparse_columns)));
    3570             : 
    3571             :     /* If it's a utility query, it won't have a jointree */

    3573             :     {
    3574             :         /* Detect whether global uniqueness of USING names is needed */
    3575         824 :         dpns->unique_using =
    3576         824 :             has_dangerous_join_using(dpns, (Node *) query->jointree);
    3577             : 
    3578             :         /*
    3579             :          * Select names for columns merged by USING, via a recursive pass over
    3580             :          * the query jointree.
    3581             :          */
    3582         824 :         set_using_names(dpns, (Node *) query->jointree, NIL);
    3583             :     }
    3584             : 
    3585             :     /*
    3586             :      * Now assign remaining column aliases for each RTE.  We do this in a
    3587             :      * linear scan of the rtable, so as to process RTEs whether or not they
    3588             :      * are in the jointree (we mustn't miss NEW.*, INSERT target relations,
    3589             :      * etc).  JOIN RTEs must be processed after their children, but this is
    3590             :      * okay because they appear later in the rtable list than their children
    3591             :      * (cf Asserts in identify_join_columns()).
    3592             :      */

    3600             :         else
    3601        2410 :             set_relation_column_names(dpns, rte, colinfo);
    3602             :     }
    3603         828 : }
    3604             : 
    3605             : /*
    3606             :  * set_simple_column_names: fill in column aliases for non-query situations
    3607             :  *
    3608             :  * This handles EXPLAIN and cases where we only have relation RTEs.  Without
    3609             :  * a join tree, we can't do anything smart about join RTEs, but we don't
    3610             :  * need to (note that EXPLAIN should never see join alias Vars anyway).
    3611             :  * If we do hit a join RTE we'll just process it like a non-table base RTE.
    3612             :  */
    3613             : static void
    3614        5426 : set_simple_column_names(deparse_namespace *dpns)
    3615             : {
    3616             :     ListCell   *lc;
    3617             :     ListCell   *lc2;
    3618             : 
    3619             :     /* Initialize dpns->rtable_columns to contain zeroed structs */
    3620        5426 :     dpns->rtable_columns = NIL;
    3621       22998 :     while (list_length(dpns->rtable_columns) < list_length(dpns->rtable))
    3622       12146 :         dpns->rtable_columns = lappend(dpns->rtable_columns,
    3623             :                                        palloc0(sizeof(deparse_columns)));
    3624             : 
    3625             :     /* Assign unique column aliases within each RTE */
    3626       17572 :     forboth(lc, dpns->rtable, lc2, dpns->rtable_columns)
    3627             :     {
    3628       12146 :         RangeTblEntry *rte = (RangeTblEntry *) lfirst(lc);
    3629       12146 :         deparse_columns *colinfo = (deparse_columns *) lfirst(lc2);
    3630             : 
    3631       12146 :         set_relation_column_names(dpns, rte, colinfo);
    3632             :     }
    3633        5426 : }
    3634             : 
    3635             : /*
    3636             :  * has_dangerous_join_using: search jointree for unnamed JOIN USING
    3637             :  *
    3638             :  * Merged columns of a JOIN USING may act differently from either of the input
    3639             :  * columns, either because they are merged with COALESCE (in a FULL JOIN) or
    3640             :  * because an implicit coercion of the underlying input column is required.
    3641             :  * In such a case the column must be referenced as a column of the JOIN not as
    3642             :  * a column of either input.  And this is problematic if the join is unnamed
    3643             :  * (alias-less): we cannot qualify the column's name with an RTE name, since
    3644             :  * there is none.  (Forcibly assigning an alias to the join is not a solution,
    3645             :  * since that will prevent legal references to tables below the join.)
    3646             :  * To ensure that every column in the query is unambiguously referenceable,
    3647             :  * we must assign such merged columns names that are globally unique across
    3648             :  * the whole query, aliasing other columns out of the way as necessary.
    3649             :  *
    3650             :  * Because the ensuing re-aliasing is fairly damaging to the readability of
    3651             :  * the query, we don't do this unless we have to.  So, we must pre-scan
    3652             :  * the join tree to see if we have to, before starting set_using_names().
    3653             :  */
    3654             : static bool
    3655        2108 : has_dangerous_join_using(deparse_namespace *dpns, Node *jtnode)
    3656             : {
    3657        2108 :     if (IsA(jtnode, RangeTblRef))
    3658             :     {
    3659             :         /* nothing to do here */
    3660             :     }
    3661        1098 :     else if (IsA(jtnode, FromExpr))
    3662             :     {
    3663         824 :         FromExpr   *f = (FromExpr *) jtnode;
    3664             :         ListCell   *lc;
    3665             : 
    3666        1584 :         foreach(lc, f->fromlist)
    3667             :         {
    3668         784 :             if (has_dangerous_join_using(dpns, (Node *) lfirst(lc)))
    3669          24 :                 return true;
    3670             :         }
    3671             :     }
    3672         274 :     else if (IsA(jtnode, JoinExpr))
    3673             :     {
    3674         274 :         JoinExpr   *j = (JoinExpr *) jtnode;
    3675             : 
    3676             :         /* Is it an unnamed JOIN with USING? */
    3677         274 :         if (j->alias == NULL && j->usingClause)
    3678             :         {
    3679             :             /*
    3680             :              * Yes, so check each join alias var to see if any of them are not
    3681             :              * simple references to underlying columns.  If so, we have a
    3682             :              * dangerous situation and must pick unique aliases.
    3683             :              */
    3684          78 :             RangeTblEntry *jrte = rt_fetch(j->rtindex, dpns->rtable);
    3685             :             ListCell   *lc;
    3686             : 
    3687         310 :             foreach(lc, jrte->joinaliasvars)
    3688             :             {
    3689         256 :                 Var        *aliasvar = (Var *) lfirst(lc);
    3690             : 
    3691         256 :                 if (aliasvar != NULL && !IsA(aliasvar, Var))
    3692          24 :                     return true;
    3693             :             }
    3694             :         }
    3695             : 
    3696             :         /* Nope, but inspect children */
    3697         250 :         if (has_dangerous_join_using(dpns, j->larg))
    3698           0 :             return true;
    3699         250 :         if (has_dangerous_join_using(dpns, j->rarg))
    3700           0 :             return true;
    3701             :     }
    3702             :     else
    3703           0 :         elog(ERROR, "unrecognized node type: %d",
    3704             :              (int) nodeTag(jtnode));
    3705        2060 :     return false;
    3706             : }
    3707             : 
    3708             : /*
    3709             :  * set_using_names: select column aliases to be used for merged USING columns
    3710             :  *
    3711             :  * We do this during a recursive descent of the query jointree.
    3712             :  * dpns->unique_using must already be set to determine the global strategy.
    3713             :  *
    3714             :  * Column alias info is saved in the dpns->rtable_columns list, which is
    3715             :  * assumed to be filled with pre-zeroed deparse_columns structs.
    3716             :  *
    3717             :  * parentUsing is a list of all USING aliases assigned in parent joins of
    3718             :  * the current jointree node.  (The passed-in list must not be modified.)
    3719             :  */
    3720             : static void
    3721        2214 : set_using_names(deparse_namespace *dpns, Node *jtnode, List *parentUsing)
    3722             : {
    3723        2214 :     if (IsA(jtnode, RangeTblRef))
    3724             :     {
    3725             :         /* nothing to do now */
    3726             :     }
    3727        1120 :     else if (IsA(jtnode, FromExpr))
    3728             :     {
    3729         824 :         FromExpr   *f = (FromExpr *) jtnode;
    3730             :         ListCell   *lc;
    3731             : 
    3732        1622 :         foreach(lc, f->fromlist)
    3733         798 :             set_using_names(dpns, (Node *) lfirst(lc), parentUsing);
    3734             :     }
    3735         296 :     else if (IsA(jtnode, JoinExpr))
    3736             :     {
    3737         296 :         JoinExpr   *j = (JoinExpr *) jtnode;
    3738         296 :         RangeTblEntry *rte = rt_fetch(j->rtindex, dpns->rtable);
    3739         296 :         deparse_columns *colinfo = deparse_columns_fetch(j->rtindex, dpns);
    3740             :         int        *leftattnos;
    3741             :         int        *rightattnos;
    3742             :         deparse_columns *leftcolinfo;
    3743             :         deparse_columns *rightcolinfo;
    3744             :         int         i;
    3745             :         ListCell   *lc;
    3746             : 
    3747             :         /* Get info about the shape of the join */
    3748         296 :         identify_join_columns(j, rte, colinfo);
    3749         296 :         leftattnos = colinfo->leftattnos;
    3750         296 :         rightattnos = colinfo->rightattnos;
    3751             : 
    3752             :         /* Look up the not-yet-filled-in child deparse_columns structs */
    3753         296 :         leftcolinfo = deparse_columns_fetch(colinfo->leftrti, dpns);
    3754         296 :         rightcolinfo = deparse_columns_fetch(colinfo->rightrti, dpns);
    3755             : 
    3756             :         /*
    3757             :          * If this join is unnamed, then we cannot substitute new aliases at
    3758             :          * this level, so any name requirements pushed down to here must be
    3759             :          * pushed down again to the children.
    3760             :          */
    3761         296 :         if (rte->alias == NULL)
    3762             :         {
    3763         310 :             for (i = 0; i < colinfo->num_cols; i++)
    3764             :             {
    3765          46 :                 char       *colname = colinfo->colnames[i];
    3766             : 
    3767          46 :                 if (colname == NULL)
    3768           8 :                     continue;
    3769             : 
    3770             :                 /* Push down to left column, unless it's a system column */
    3771          38 :                 if (leftattnos[i] > 0)
    3772             :                 {
    3773          34 :                     expand_colnames_array_to(leftcolinfo, leftattnos[i]);
    3774          34 :                     leftcolinfo->colnames[leftattnos[i] - 1] = colname;
    3775             :                 }
    3776             : 
    3777             :                 /* Same on the righthand side */
    3778          38 :                 if (rightattnos[i] > 0)
    3779             :                 {
    3780          38 :                     expand_colnames_array_to(rightcolinfo, rightattnos[i]);
    3781          38 :                     rightcolinfo->colnames[rightattnos[i] - 1] = colname;
    3782             :                 }
    3783             :             }
    3784             :         }
    3785             : 
    3786             :         /*
    3787             :          * If there's a USING clause, select the USING column names and push
    3788             :          * those names down to the children.  We have two strategies:
    3789             :          *
    3790             :          * If dpns->unique_using is true, we force all USING names to be
    3791             :          * unique across the whole query level.  In principle we'd only need
    3792             :          * the names of dangerous USING columns to be globally unique, but to
    3793             :          * safely assign all USING names in a single pass, we have to enforce
    3794             :          * the same uniqueness rule for all of them.  However, if a USING
    3795             :          * column's name has been pushed down from the parent, we should use
    3796             :          * it as-is rather than making a uniqueness adjustment.  This is
    3797             :          * necessary when we're at an unnamed join, and it creates no risk of
    3798             :          * ambiguity.  Also, if there's a user-written output alias for a
    3799             :          * merged column, we prefer to use that rather than the input name;
    3800             :          * this simplifies the logic and seems likely to lead to less aliasing
    3801             :          * overall.
    3802             :          *
    3803             :          * If dpns->unique_using is false, we only need USING names to be
    3804             :          * unique within their own join RTE.  We still need to honor
    3805             :          * pushed-down names, though.
    3806             :          *
    3807             :          * Though significantly different in results, these two strategies are
    3808             :          * implemented by the same code, with only the difference of whether
    3809             :          * to put assigned names into dpns->using_names.
    3810             :          */
    3811         296 :         if (j->usingClause)
    3812             :         {
    3813             :             /* Copy the input parentUsing list so we don't modify it */
    3814         120 :             parentUsing = list_copy(parentUsing);
    3815             : 
    3816             :             /* USING names must correspond to the first join output columns */
    3817         120 :             expand_colnames_array_to(colinfo, list_length(j->usingClause));
    3818         120 :             i = 0;
    3819         292 :             foreach(lc, j->usingClause)
    3820             :             {
    3821         172 :                 char       *colname = strVal(lfirst(lc));
    3822             : 
    3823             :                 /* Assert it's a merged column */
    3824         172 :                 Assert(leftattnos[i] != 0 && rightattnos[i] != 0);
    3825             : 
    3826             :                 /* Adopt passed-down name if any, else select unique name */
    3827         172 :                 if (colinfo->colnames[i] != NULL)
    3828          34 :                     colname = colinfo->colnames[i];
    3829             :                 else
    3830             :                 {
    3831             :                     /* Prefer user-written output alias if any */
    3832         138 :                     if (rte->alias && i < list_length(rte->alias->colnames))
    3833           0 :                         colname = strVal(list_nth(rte->alias->colnames, i));
    3834             :                     /* Make it appropriately unique */
    3835         138 :                     colname = make_colname_unique(colname, dpns, colinfo);
    3836         138 :                     if (dpns->unique_using)
    3837          42 :                         dpns->using_names = lappend(dpns->using_names,
    3838             :                                                     colname);
    3839             :                     /* Save it as output column name, too */
    3840         138 :                     colinfo->colnames[i] = colname;
    3841             :                 }
    3842             : 
    3843             :                 /* Remember selected names for use later */
    3844         172 :                 colinfo->usingNames = lappend(colinfo->usingNames, colname);
    3845         172 :                 parentUsing = lappend(parentUsing, colname);
    3846             : 
    3847             :                 /* Push down to left column, unless it's a system column */
    3848         172 :                 if (leftattnos[i] > 0)
    3849             :                 {
    3850         172 :                     expand_colnames_array_to(leftcolinfo, leftattnos[i]);
    3851         172 :                     leftcolinfo->colnames[leftattnos[i] - 1] = colname;
    3852             :                 }
    3853             : 
    3854             :                 /* Same on the righthand side */
    3855         172 :                 if (rightattnos[i] > 0)
    3856             :                 {
    3857         172 :                     expand_colnames_array_to(rightcolinfo, rightattnos[i]);
    3858         172 :                     rightcolinfo->colnames[rightattnos[i] - 1] = colname;
    3859             :                 }
    3860             : 
    3861         172 :                 i++;
    3862             :             }
    3863             :         }
    3864             : 
    3865             :         /* Mark child deparse_columns structs with correct parentUsing info */
    3866         296 :         leftcolinfo->parentUsing = parentUsing;
    3867         296 :         rightcolinfo->parentUsing = parentUsing;
    3868             : 
    3869             :         /* Now recursively assign USING column names in children */
    3870         296 :         set_using_names(dpns, j->larg, parentUsing);
    3871         296 :         set_using_names(dpns, j->rarg, parentUsing);
    3872             :     }
    3873             :     else
    3874           0 :         elog(ERROR, "unrecognized node type: %d",
    3875             :              (int) nodeTag(jtnode));
    3876        2214 : }
    3877             : 
    3878             : /*
    3879             :  * set_relation_column_names: select column aliases for a non-join RTE
    3880             :  *
    3881             :  * Column alias info is saved in *colinfo, which is assumed to be pre-zeroed.
    3882             :  * If any colnames entries are already filled in, those override local

    4025             : 
    4026             :     /*
    4027             :      * For a relation RTE, we need only print the alias column names if any
    4028             :      * are different from the underlying "real" names.  For a function RTE,
    4029             :      * always emit a complete column alias list; this is to protect against
    4030             :      * possible instability of the default column names (eg, from altering
    4031             :      * parameter names).  For tablefunc RTEs, we never print aliases, because
    4032             :      * the column names are part of the clause itself.  For other RTE types,
    4033             :      * print if we changed anything OR if there were user-written column
    4034             :      * aliases (since the latter would be part of the underlying "reality").
    4035             :      */

    4037       12342 :         colinfo->printaliases = changed_any;
    4038        2214 :     else if (rte->rtekind == RTE_FUNCTION)
    4039         180 :         colinfo->printaliases = true;
    4040        2034 :     else if (rte->rtekind == RTE_TABLEFUNC)
    4041          12 :         colinfo->printaliases = false;
    4042        2022 :     else if (rte->alias && rte->alias->colnames != NIL)
    4043         100 :         colinfo->printaliases = true;

    4048             : /*

    4159             :     /*
    4160             :      * Generating the new_colnames array is a bit tricky since any new columns
    4161             :      * added since parse time must be inserted in the right places.  This code
    4162             :      * must match the parser, which will order a join's columns as merged
    4163             :      * columns first (in USING-clause order), then non-merged columns from the
    4164             :      * left input (in attnum order), then non-merged columns from the right
    4165             :      * input (ditto).  If one of the inputs is itself a join, its columns will
    4166             :      * be ordered according to the same rule, which means newly-added columns
    4167             :      * might not be at the end.  We can figure out what's what by consulting
    4168             :      * the leftattnos and rightattnos arrays plus the input is_new_col arrays.
    4169             :      *
    4170             :      * In these loops, i indexes leftattnos/rightattnos (so it's join varattno
    4171             :      * less one), j indexes new_colnames/is_new_col, and ic/jc have similar
    4172             :      * meanings for the current child RTE.
    4173             :      */
    4174             :

    4496          34 :         else if (IsA(aliasvar, CoalesceExpr))
    4497             :         {
    4498             :             /*
    4499             :              * It's a merged column in FULL JOIN USING.  Ignore it for now and
    4500             :              * let the code below identify the merged columns.
    4501             :              */
    4502             :         }
    4503             :         else
    4504           0 :             elog(ERROR, "unrecognized node type in join alias vars: %d",
    4505             :                  (int) nodeTag(aliasvar));
    4506             : 
    4507        7694 :         i++;
    4508             :     }
    4509             : 
    4510             :     /*
    4511             :      * If there's a USING clause, deconstruct the join quals to identify the
    4512             :      * merged columns.  This is a tad painful but if we cannot rely on the
    4513             :      * column names, there is no other representation of which columns were
    4514             :      * joined by USING.  (Unless the join type is FULL, we can't tell from the
    4515             :      * joinaliasvars list which columns are merged.)  Note: we assume that the
    4516             :      * merged columns are the first output column(s) of the join.
    4517             :      */
    4518         296 :     if (j->usingClause)
    4519             :     {
    4520         120 :         List       *leftvars = NIL;
    4521         120 :         List       *rightvars = NIL;
    4522             :         ListCell   *lc2;
    4523             : 
    4524             :         /* Extract left- and right-side Vars from the qual expression */
    4525         120 :         flatten_join_using_qual(j->quals, &leftvars, &rightvars);
    4526         120 :         Assert(list_length(leftvars) == list_length(j->usingClause));
    4527         120 :         Assert(list_length(rightvars) == list_length(j->usingClause));
    4528             : 
    4529             :         /* Mark the output columns accordingly */
    4530         120 :         i = 0;
    4531         292 :         forboth(lc, leftvars, lc2, rightvars)
    4532             :         {
    4533         172 :             Var        *leftvar = (Var *) lfirst(lc);
    4534         172 :             Var        *rightvar = (Var *) lfirst(lc2);
    4535             : 
    4536         172 :             Assert(leftvar->varlevelsup == 0);
    4537         172 :             Assert(leftvar->varattno != 0);
    4538         172 :             if (leftvar->varno != colinfo->leftrti)
    4539           0 :                 elog(ERROR, "unexpected varno %d in JOIN USING qual",
    4540             :                      leftvar->varno);
    4541         172 :             colinfo->leftattnos[i] = leftvar->varattno;
    4542             : 
    4543         172 :             Assert(rightvar->varlevelsup == 0);
    4544         172 :             Assert(rightvar->varattno != 0);
    4545         172 :             if (rightvar->varno != colinfo->rightrti)
    4546           0 :                 elog(ERROR, "unexpected varno %d in JOIN USING qual",
    4547             :                      rightvar->varno);
    4548         172 :             colinfo->rightattnos[i] = rightvar->varattno;
    4549             : 
    4550         172 :             i++;
    4551             :         }
    4552             :     }
    4553         296 : }
    4554             : 
    4555             : /*
    4556             :  * flatten_join_using_qual: extract Vars being joined from a JOIN/USING qual
    4557             :  *
    4558             :  * We assume that transformJoinUsingClause won't have produced anything except
    4559             :  * AND nodes, equality operator nodes, and possibly implicit coercions, and
    4560             :  * that the AND node inputs match left-to-right with the original USING list.
    4561             :  *
    4562             :  * Caller must initialize the result lists to NIL.
    4563             :  */
    4564             : static void
    4565         224 : flatten_join_using_qual(Node *qual, List **leftvars, List **rightvars)
    4566             : {
    4567         224 :     if (IsA(qual, BoolExpr))
    4568             :     {
    4569             :         /* Handle AND nodes by recursion */
    4570          52 :         BoolExpr   *b = (BoolExpr *) qual;
    4571             :         ListCell   *lc;
    4572             : 
    4573          52 :         Assert(b->boolop == AND_EXPR);
    4574         156 :         foreach(lc, b->args)
    4575             :         {
    4576         104 :             flatten_join_using_qual((Node *) lfirst(lc),
    4577             :                                     leftvars, rightvars);
    4578             :         }
    4579             :     }
    4580         172 :     else if (IsA(qual, OpExpr))
    4581             :     {
    4582             :         /* Otherwise we should have an equality operator */
    4583         172 :         OpExpr     *op = (OpExpr *) qual;
    4584             :         Var        *var;
    4585             : 
    4586         172 :         if (list_length(op->args) != 2)
    4587           0 :             elog(ERROR, "unexpected unary operator in JOIN/USING qual");
    4588             :         /* Arguments should be Vars with perhaps implicit coercions */
    4589         172 :         var = (Var *) strip_implicit_coercions((Node *) linitial(op->args));
    4590         172 :         if (!IsA(var, Var))
    4591           0 :             elog(ERROR, "unexpected node type in JOIN/USING qual: %d",
    4592             :                  (int) nodeTag(var));
    4593         172 :         *leftvars = lappend(*leftvars, var);
    4594         172 :         var = (Var *) strip_implicit_coercions((Node *) lsecond(op->args));
    4595         172 :         if (!IsA(var, Var))
    4596           0 :             elog(ERROR, "unexpected node type in JOIN/USING qual: %d",
    4597             :                  (int) nodeTag(var));
    4598         172 :         *rightvars = lappend(*rightvars, var);
    4599             :     }
    4600             :     else
    4601             :     {
    4602             :         /* Perhaps we have an implicit coercion to boolean? */
    4603           0 :         Node       *q = strip_implicit_coercions(qual);
    4604             : 
    4605           0 :         if (q != qual)
    4606           0 :             flatten_join_using_qual(q, leftvars, rightvars);
    4607             :         else
    4608           0 :             elog(ERROR, "unexpected node type in JOIN/USING qual: %d",
    4609             :                  (int) nodeTag(qual));
    4610             :     }
    4611         224 : }
    4612             : 
    4613             : /*
    4614             :  * get_rtable_name: convenience function to get a previously assigned RTE alias
    4615             :  *
    4616             :  * The RTE must belong to the topmost namespace level in "context".
    4617             :  */
    4618             : static char *
    4619         994 : get_rtable_name(int rtindex, deparse_context *context)
    4620             : {
    4621         994 :     deparse_namespace *dpns = (deparse_namespace *) linitial(context->namespaces);
    4622             : 
    4623         994 :     Assert(rtindex > 0 && rtindex <= list_length(dpns->rtable_names));
    4624         994 :     return (char *) list_nth(dpns->rtable_names, rtindex - 1);
    4625             : }
    4626             : 
    4627             : /*
    4628             :  * set_deparse_planstate: set up deparse_namespace to parse subexpressions
    4629             :  * of a given PlanState node
    4630             :  *
    4631             :  * This sets the planstate, outer_planstate, inner_planstate, outer_tlist,
    4632             :  * inner_tlist, and index_tlist fields.  Caller is responsible for adjusting
    4633             :  * the ancestors list if necessary.  Note that the rtable and ctes fields do
    4634             :  * not need to change when shifting attention to different plan nodes in a
    4635             :  * single plan tree.
    4636             :  */
    4637             : static void
    4638       18142 : set_deparse_planstate(deparse_namespace *dpns, PlanState *ps)
    4639             : {
    4640       18142 :     dpns->planstate = ps;
    4641             : 
    4642             :     /*
    4643             :      * We special-case Append and MergeAppend to pretend that the first child
    4644             :      * plan is the OUTER referent; we have to interpret OUTER Vars in their
    4645             :      * tlists according to one of the children, and the first one is the most
    4646             :      * natural choice.  Likewise special-case ModifyTable to pretend that the
    4647             :      * first child plan is the OUTER referent; this is to support RETURNING
    4648             :      * lists containing references to non-target relations.
    4649             :      */
    4650       18142 :     if (IsA(ps, AppendState))
    4651         636 :         dpns->outer_planstate = ((AppendState *) ps)->appendplans[0];
    4652       17506 :     else if (IsA(ps, MergeAppendState))
    4653         110 :         dpns->outer_planstate = ((MergeAppendState *) ps)->mergeplans[0];
    4654       17396 :     else if (IsA(ps, ModifyTableState))
    4655          54 :         dpns->outer_planstate = ((ModifyTableState *) ps)->mt_plans[0];
    4656             :     else
    4657       17342 :         dpns->outer_planstate = outerPlanState(ps);
    4658             : 
    4659       18142 :     if (dpns->outer_planstate)
    4660        7864 :         dpns->outer_tlist = dpns->outer_planstate->plan->targetlist;
    4661             :     else
    4662       10278 :         dpns->outer_tlist = NIL;
    4663             : 
    4664             :     /*
    4665             :      * For a SubqueryScan, pretend the subplan is INNER referent.  (We don't
    4666             :      * use OUTER because that could someday conflict with the normal meaning.)
    4667             :      * Likewise, for a CteScan, pretend the subquery's plan is INNER referent.
    4668             :      * For ON CONFLICT .. UPDATE we just need the inner tlist to point to the
    4669             :      * excluded expression's tlist. (Similar to the SubqueryScan we don't want
    4670             :      * to reuse OUTER, it's used for RETURNING in some modify table cases,
    4671             :      * although not INSERT .. CONFLICT).
    4672             :      */
    4673       18142 :     if (IsA(ps, SubqueryScanState))
    4674          96 :         dpns->inner_planstate = ((SubqueryScanState *) ps)->subplan;
    4675       18046 :     else if (IsA(ps, CteScanState))
    4676          84 :         dpns->inner_planstate = ((CteScanState *) ps)->cteplanstate;
    4677       17962 :     else if (IsA(ps, ModifyTableState))
    4678          54 :         dpns->inner_planstate = ps;
    4679             :     else
    4680       17908 :         dpns->inner_planstate = innerPlanState(ps);
    4681             : 
    4682       18142 :     if (IsA(ps, ModifyTableState))
    4683          54 :         dpns->inner_tlist = ((ModifyTableState *) ps)->mt_excludedtlist;
    4684       18088 :     else if (dpns->inner_planstate)
    4685        2918 :         dpns->inner_tlist = dpns->inner_planstate->plan->targetlist;
    4686             :     else
    4687       15170 :         dpns->inner_tlist = NIL;
    4688             : 
    4689             :     /* Set up referent for INDEX_VAR Vars, if needed */
    4690       18142 :     if (IsA(ps->plan, IndexOnlyScan))
    4691         534 :         dpns->index_tlist = ((IndexOnlyScan *) ps->plan)->indextlist;
    4692       17608 :     else if (IsA(ps->plan, ForeignScan))
    4693           0 :         dpns->index_tlist = ((ForeignScan *) ps->plan)->fdw_scan_tlist;
    4694       17608 :     else if (IsA(ps->plan, CustomScan))
    4695           0 :         dpns->index_tlist = ((CustomScan *) ps->plan)->custom_scan_tlist;
    4696             :     else
    4697       17608 :         dpns->index_tlist = NIL;
    4698       18142 : }
    4699             : 
    4700             : /*
    4701             :  * push_child_plan: temporarily transfer deparsing attention to a child plan
    4702             :  *
    4703             :  * When expanding an OUTER_VAR or INNER_VAR reference, we must adjust the
    4704             :  * deparse context in case the referenced expression itself uses
    4705             :  * OUTER_VAR/INNER_VAR.  We modify the top stack entry in-place to avoid
    4706             :  * affecting levelsup issues (although in a Plan tree there really shouldn't
    4707             :  * be any).
    4708             :  *
    4709             :  * Caller must provide a local deparse_namespace variable to save the
    4710             :  * previous state for pop_child_plan.
    4711             :  */
    4712             : static void
    4713        9016 : push_child_plan(deparse_namespace *dpns, PlanState *ps,
    4714             :                 deparse_namespace *save_dpns)
    4715             : {
    4716             :     /* Save state for restoration later */
    4717        9016 :     *save_dpns = *dpns;
    4718             : 
    4719             :     /* Link current plan node into ancestors list */
    4720        9016 :     dpns->ancestors = lcons(dpns->planstate, dpns->ancestors);
    4721             : 
    4722             :     /* Set attention on selected child */
    4723        9016 :     set_deparse_planstate(dpns, ps);
    4724        9016 : }
    4725             : 
    4726             : /*
    4727             :  * pop_child_plan: undo the effects of push_child_plan
    4728             :  */
    4729             : static void
    4730        9016 : pop_child_plan(deparse_namespace *dpns, deparse_namespace *save_dpns)
    4731             : {
    4732             :     List       *ancestors;
    4733             : 
    4734             :     /* Get rid of ancestors list cell added by push_child_plan */
    4735        9016 :     ancestors = list_delete_first(dpns->ancestors);
    4736             : 
    4737             :     /* Restore fields changed by push_child_plan */
    4738        9016 :     *dpns = *save_dpns;
    4739             : 
    4740             :     /* Make sure dpns->ancestors is right (may be unnecessary) */
    4741        9016 :     dpns->ancestors = ancestors;
    4742        9016 : }
    4743             : 
    4744             : /*
    4745             :  * push_ancestor_plan: temporarily transfer deparsing attention to an
    4746             :  * ancestor plan
    4747             :  *
    4748             :  * When expanding a Param reference, we must adjust the deparse context
    4749             :  * to match the plan node that contains the expression being printed;
    4750             :  * otherwise we'd fail if that expression itself contains a Param or
    4751             :  * OUTER_VAR/INNER_VAR/INDEX_VAR variable.
    4752             :  *
    4753             :  * The target ancestor is conveniently identified by the ListCell holding it
    4754             :  * in dpns->ancestors.
    4755             :  *
    4756             :  * Caller must provide a local deparse_namespace variable to save the
    4757             :  * previous state for pop_ancestor_plan.
    4758             :  */
    4759             : static void
    4760         718 : push_ancestor_plan(deparse_namespace *dpns, ListCell *ancestor_cell,
    4761             :                    deparse_namespace *save_dpns)
    4762             : {
    4763         718 :     PlanState  *ps = (PlanState *) lfirst(ancestor_cell);
    4764             : 
    4765             :     /* Save state for restoration later */
    4766         718 :     *save_dpns = *dpns;
    4767             : 
    4768             :     /* Build a new ancestor list with just this node's ancestors */
    4769         718 :     dpns->ancestors =
    4770         718 :         list_copy_tail(dpns->ancestors,
    4771         718 :                        list_cell_number(dpns->ancestors, ancestor_cell) + 1);
    4772             : 
    4773             :     /* Set attention on selected ancestor */
    4774         718 :     set_deparse_planstate(dpns, ps);
    4775         718 : }
    4776             : 
    4777             : /*
    4778             :  * pop_ancestor_plan: undo the effects of push_ancestor_plan
    4779             :  */
    4780             : static void
    4781         718 : pop_ancestor_plan(deparse_namespace *dpns, deparse_namespace *save_dpns)
    4782             : {
    4783             :     /* Free the ancestor list made in push_ancestor_plan */
    4784         718 :     list_free(dpns->ancestors);
    4785             : 
    4786             :     /* Restore fields changed by push_ancestor_plan */
    4787         718 :     *dpns = *save_dpns;
    4788         718 : }
    4789             : 
    4790             : 
    4791             : /* ----------
    4792             :  * make_ruledef         - reconstruct the CREATE RULE command

    4983             : /* ----------

    5056             : /* ----------
    5057             :  * get_query_def            - Parse back one query parsetree
    5058             :  *

    5063             : static void
    5064         806 : get_query_def(Query *query, StringInfo buf, List *parentnamespace,
    5065             :               TupleDesc resultDesc,
    5066             :               int prettyFlags, int wrapColumn, int startIndent)
    5067             : {
    5068             :     deparse_context context;
    5069             :     deparse_namespace dpns;
    5070             : 
    5071             :     /* Guard against excessively long or deeply-nested queries */
    5072         806 :     CHECK_FOR_INTERRUPTS();
    5073         806 :     check_stack_depth();
    5074             : 
    5075             :     /*
    5076             :      * Before we begin to examine the query, acquire locks on referenced
    5077             :      * relations, and fix up deleted columns in JOIN RTEs.  This ensures
    5078             :      * consistent results.  Note we assume it's OK to scribble on the passed
    5079             :      * querytree!
    5080             :      *
    5081             :      * We are only deparsing the query (we are not about to execute it), so we
    5082             :      * only need AccessShareLock on the relations it mentions.
    5083             :      */
    5084         806 :     AcquireRewriteLocks(query, false, false);
    5085             : 
    5086         806 :     context.buf = buf;
    5087         806 :     context.namespaces = lcons(&dpns, list_copy(parentnamespace));

    5090        1390 :     context.varprefix = (parentnamespace != NIL ||
    5091         584 :                          list_length(query->rtable) != 1);
    5092         806 :     context.prettyFlags = prettyFlags;
    5093         806 :     context.wrapColumn = wrapColumn;
    5094         806 :     context.indentLevel = startIndent;
    5095         806 :     context.special_exprkind = EXPR_KIND_NONE;

    5100             :     {

    5372             : /*

    5377             : static RangeTblEntry *
    5378         678 : get_simple_values_rte(Query *query, TupleDesc resultDesc)
    5379             : {
    5380         678 :     RangeTblEntry *result = NULL;

    5383             :     /*

    5386             :      * one inFromCl RTE that is a VALUES RTE.

    5397             :         }

    5408             :      * structure.  However, DefineView might have modified the tlist by
    5409             :      * injecting new column aliases, or we might have some other column

    5446             : static void

    5512             :     }
