    5567             : /* ----------
    5568             :  * get_target_list          - Parse back a SELECT target list
    5569             :  *
    5570             :  * This is also used for RETURNING lists in INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE.
    5571             :  * ----------
    5572             :  */
    5573             : static void
    5574         640 : get_target_list(List *targetList, deparse_context *context,
    5575             :                 TupleDesc resultDesc)
    5576             : {
    5577         640 :     StringInfo  buf = context->buf;
    5578             :     StringInfoData targetbuf;
    5579         640 :     bool        last_was_multiline = false;
    5580             :     char       *sep;
    5581             :     int         colno;
    5582             :     ListCell   *l;
    5583             : 
    5584             :     /* we use targetbuf to hold each TLE's text temporarily */
    5585         640 :     initStringInfo(&targetbuf);
    5586             : 
    5587         640 :     sep = " ";
    5588         640 :     colno = 0;
    5589        3452 :     foreach(l, targetList)
    5590             :     {
    5591        2812 :         TargetEntry *tle = (TargetEntry *) lfirst(l);
    5592             :         char       *colname;
    5593             :         char       *attname;
    5594             : 
    5595        2812 :         if (tle->resjunk)
    5596          14 :             continue;           /* ignore junk entries */
    5597             : 
    5598        2798 :         appendStringInfoString(buf, sep);
    5599        2798 :         sep = ", ";
    5600        2798 :         colno++;
    5601             : 
    5602             :         /*
    5603             :          * Put the new field text into targetbuf so we can decide after we've
    5604             :          * got it whether or not it needs to go on a new line.
    5605             :          */
    5606        2798 :         resetStringInfo(&targetbuf);
    5607        2798 :         context->buf = &targetbuf;
    5608             : 
    5609             :         /*
    5610             :          * We special-case Var nodes rather than using get_rule_expr. This is
    5611             :          * needed because get_rule_expr will display a whole-row Var as
    5612             :          * "foo.*", which is the preferred notation in most contexts, but at
    5613             :          * the top level of a SELECT list it's not right (the parser will
    5614             :          * expand that notation into multiple columns, yielding behavior
    5615             :          * different from a whole-row Var).  We need to call get_variable
    5616             :          * directly so that we can tell it to do the right thing, and so that
    5617             :          * we can get the attribute name which is the default AS label.
    5618             :          */
    5619        2798 :         if (tle->expr && (IsA(tle->expr, Var)))
    5620             :         {
    5621        2260 :             attname = get_variable((Var *) tle->expr, 0, true, context);
    5622             :         }
    5623             :         else
    5624             :         {
    5625         538 :             get_rule_expr((Node *) tle->expr, context, true);
    5626             :             /* We'll show the AS name unless it's this: */
    5627         538 :             attname = "?column?";
    5628             :         }
    5629             : 
    5630             :         /*
    5631             :          * Figure out what the result column should be called.  In the context
    5632             :          * of a view, use the view's tuple descriptor (so as to pick up the
    5633             :          * effects of any column RENAME that's been done on the view).
    5634             :          * Otherwise, just use what we can find in the TLE.
    5635             :          */
    5636        2798 :         if (resultDesc && colno <= resultDesc->natts)
    5637        2636 :             colname = NameStr(TupleDescAttr(resultDesc, colno - 1)->attname);
    5638             :         else
    5639         162 :             colname = tle->resname;
    5640             : 
    5641             :         /* Show AS unless the column's name is correct as-is */
    5642        2798 :         if (colname)            /* resname could be NULL */
    5643             :         {
    5644        2798 :             if (attname == NULL || strcmp(attname, colname) != 0)
    5645         832 :                 appendStringInfo(&targetbuf, " AS %s", quote_identifier(colname));
    5646             :         }
    5647             : 
    5648             :         /* Restore context's output buffer */
    5649        2798 :         context->buf = buf;
    5650             : 
    5651             :         /* Consider line-wrapping if enabled */
    5652        2798 :         if (PRETTY_INDENT(context) && context->wrapColumn >= 0)
    5653             :         {
    5654             :             int         leading_nl_pos;
    5655             : 
    5656             :             /* Does the new field start with a new line? */
    5657        2798 :             if (targetbuf.len > 0 && targetbuf.data[0] == '\n')
    5658          48 :                 leading_nl_pos = 0;
    5659             :             else
    5660        2750 :                 leading_nl_pos = -1;
    5661             : 
    5662             :             /* If so, we shouldn't add anything */
    5663        2798 :             if (leading_nl_pos >= 0)
    5664             :             {
    5665             :                 /* instead, remove any trailing spaces currently in buf */
    5666          48 :                 removeStringInfoSpaces(buf);
    5667             :             }
    5668             :             else
    5669             :             {
    5670             :                 char       *trailing_nl;
    5671             : 
    5672             :                 /* Locate the start of the current line in the output buffer */
    5673        2750 :                 trailing_nl = strrchr(buf->data, '\n');
    5674        2750 :                 if (trailing_nl == NULL)
    5675         894 :                     trailing_nl = buf->data;
    5676             :                 else
    5677        1856 :                     trailing_nl++;
    5678             : 
    5679             :                 /*
    5680             :                  * Add a newline, plus some indentation, if the new field is

    5682             :                  * overflow or the last field used more than one line.
    5683             :                  */

    5685        2112 :                     ((strlen(trailing_nl) + targetbuf.len > context->wrapColumn) ||
    5686             :                      last_was_multiline))
    5687        2112 :                     appendContextKeyword(context, "", -PRETTYINDENT_STD,
    5688             :                                          PRETTYINDENT_STD, PRETTYINDENT_VAR);
    5689             :             }
    5690             : 
    5691             :             /* Remember this field's multiline status for next iteration */
    5692        2798 :             last_was_multiline =
    5693        2798 :                 (strchr(targetbuf.data + leading_nl_pos + 1, '\n') != NULL);
    5694             :         }
    5695             : 
    5696             :         /* Add the new field */
    5697        2798 :         appendBinaryStringInfo(buf, targetbuf.data, targetbuf.len);
    5698             :     }
    5699             : 
    5700             :     /* clean up */
    5701         640 :     pfree(targetbuf.data);
    5702         640 : }

    5704             : static void
    5705         146 : get_setop_query(Node *setOp, Query *query, deparse_context *context,
    5706             :                 TupleDesc resultDesc)
    5707             : {
    5708         146 :     StringInfo  buf = context->buf;
    5709             :     bool        need_paren;
    5710             : 
    5711             :     /* Guard against excessively long or deeply-nested queries */
    5712         146 :     CHECK_FOR_INTERRUPTS();
    5713         146 :     check_stack_depth();
    5714             : 
    5715         146 :     if (IsA(setOp, RangeTblRef))
    5716             :     {
    5717          90 :         RangeTblRef *rtr = (RangeTblRef *) setOp;
    5718          90 :         RangeTblEntry *rte = rt_fetch(rtr->rtindex, query->rtable);
    5719          90 :         Query      *subquery = rte->subquery;
    5720             : 
    5721          90 :         Assert(subquery != NULL);
    5722          90 :         Assert(subquery->setOperations == NULL);
    5723             :         /* Need parens if WITH, ORDER BY, FOR UPDATE, or LIMIT; see gram.y */
    5724         270 :         need_paren = (subquery->cteList ||
    5725         180 :                       subquery->sortClause ||
    5726         180 :                       subquery->rowMarks ||
    5727         270 :                       subquery->limitOffset ||
    5728          90 :                       subquery->limitCount);
    5729          90 :         if (need_paren)
    5730           0 :             appendStringInfoChar(buf, '(');
    5731          90 :         get_query_def(subquery, buf, context->namespaces, resultDesc,
    5732             :                       context->prettyFlags, context->wrapColumn,
    5733             :                       context->indentLevel);
    5734          90 :         if (need_paren)
    5735           0 :             appendStringInfoChar(buf, ')');
    5736             :     }
    5737          56 :     else if (IsA(setOp, SetOperationStmt))
    5738             :     {
    5739          56 :         SetOperationStmt *op = (SetOperationStmt *) setOp;
    5740             :         int         subindent;
    5741             : 
    5742             :         /*
    5743             :          * We force parens when nesting two SetOperationStmts, except when the
    5744             :          * lefthand input is another setop of the same kind.  Syntactically,
    5745             :          * we could omit parens in rather more cases, but it seems best to use
    5746             :          * parens to flag cases where the setop operator changes.  If we use
    5747             :          * parens, we also increase the indentation level for the child query.
    5748             :          *
    5749             :          * There are some cases in which parens are needed around a leaf query
    5750             :          * too, but those are more easily handled at the next level down (see
    5751             :          * code above).
    5752             :          */
    5753          56 :         if (IsA(op->larg, SetOperationStmt))
    5754             :         {
    5755          22 :             SetOperationStmt *lop = (SetOperationStmt *) op->larg;
    5756             : 
    5757          22 :             if (op->op == lop->op && op->all == lop->all)
    5758          22 :                 need_paren = false;
    5759             :             else
    5760           0 :                 need_paren = true;
    5761             :         }
    5762             :         else
    5763          34 :             need_paren = false;
    5764             : 
    5765          56 :         if (need_paren)
    5766             :         {
    5767           0 :             appendStringInfoChar(buf, '(');
    5768           0 :             subindent = PRETTYINDENT_STD;
    5769           0 :             appendContextKeyword(context, "", subindent, 0, 0);
    5770             :         }
    5771             :         else
    5772          56 :             subindent = 0;
    5773             : 
    5774          56 :         get_setop_query(op->larg, query, context, resultDesc);
    5775             : 
    5776          56 :         if (need_paren)
    5777           0 :             appendContextKeyword(context, ") ", -subindent, 0, 0);
    5778          56 :         else if (PRETTY_INDENT(context))
    5779          56 :             appendContextKeyword(context, "", -subindent, 0, 0);
    5780             :         else
    5781           0 :             appendStringInfoChar(buf, ' ');
    5782             : 
    5783          56 :         switch (op->op)
    5784             :         {
    5785             :             case SETOP_UNION:
    5786          56 :                 appendStringInfoString(buf, "UNION ");
    5787          56 :                 break;
    5788             :             case SETOP_INTERSECT:
    5789           0 :                 appendStringInfoString(buf, "INTERSECT ");
    5790           0 :                 break;

    5792           0 :                 appendStringInfoString(buf, "EXCEPT ");
    5793           0 :                 break;

    5808             :          */

    5810             :         {
    5811           0 :             appendStringInfoChar(buf, '(');

    5832             : /*
    5833             :  * Display a sort/group clause.
    5834             :  *
    5835             :  * Also returns the expression tree, so caller need not find it again.
    5836             :  */
    5837             : static Node *
    5838         104 : get_rule_sortgroupclause(Index ref, List *tlist, bool force_colno,
    5839             :                          deparse_context *context)
    5840             : {
    5841         104 :     StringInfo  buf = context->buf;
    5842             :     TargetEntry *tle;
    5843             :     Node       *expr;
    5844             : 
    5845         104 :     tle = get_sortgroupref_tle(ref, tlist);
    5846         104 :     expr = (Node *) tle->expr;
    5847             : 
    5848             :     /*
    5849             :      * Use column-number form if requested by caller.  Otherwise, if
    5850             :      * expression is a constant, force it to be dumped with an explicit cast
    5851             :      * as decoration --- this is because a simple integer constant is
    5852             :      * ambiguous (and will be misinterpreted by findTargetlistEntry()) if we
    5853             :      * dump it without any decoration.  If it's anything more complex than a
    5854             :      * simple Var, then force extra parens around it, to ensure it can't be
    5855             :      * misinterpreted as a cube() or rollup() construct.
    5856             :      */
    5857         104 :     if (force_colno)
    5858             :     {
    5859           0 :         Assert(!tle->resjunk);
    5860           0 :         appendStringInfo(buf, "%d", tle->resno);
    5861             :     }
    5862         104 :     else if (expr && IsA(expr, Const))
    5863           0 :         get_const_expr((Const *) expr, context, 1);
    5864         104 :     else if (!expr || IsA(expr, Var))
    5865          98 :         get_rule_expr(expr, context, true);
    5866             :     else
    5867             :     {
    5868             :         /*
    5869             :          * We must force parens for function-like expressions even if
    5870             :          * PRETTY_PAREN is off, since those are the ones in danger of
    5871             :          * misparsing. For other expressions we need to force them only if
    5872             :          * PRETTY_PAREN is on, since otherwise the expression will output them
    5873             :          * itself. (We can't skip the parens.)
    5874             :          */
    5875          12 :         bool        need_paren = (PRETTY_PAREN(context)
    5876           6 :                                   || IsA(expr, FuncExpr)
    5877           6 :                                   ||IsA(expr, Aggref)
    5878          12 :                                   ||IsA(expr, WindowFunc));
    5879             : 
    5880           6 :         if (need_paren)
    5881           0 :             appendStringInfoChar(context->buf, '(');
    5882           6 :         get_rule_expr(expr, context, true);
    5883           6 :         if (need_paren)
    5884           0 :             appendStringInfoChar(context->buf, ')');
    5885             :     }
    5886             : 
    5887         104 :     return expr;
    5888             : }

    5977             :         {

    5979          52 :             if (srt->nulls_first)
    5980           0 :                 appendStringInfoString(buf, " NULLS FIRST");
    5981             :         }

    5983             :         {

    6004             : 
    6005             : /*
    6006             :  * Display a WINDOW clause.
    6007             :  *
    6008             :  * Note that the windowClause list might contain only anonymous window
    6009             :  * specifications, in which case we should print nothing here.
    6010             :  */
    6011             : static void
    6012          14 : get_rule_windowclause(Query *query, deparse_context *context)
    6013             : {
    6014          14 :     StringInfo  buf = context->buf;
    6015             :     const char *sep;
    6016             :     ListCell   *l;
    6017             : 
    6018          14 :     sep = NULL;
    6019          28 :     foreach(l, query->windowClause)
    6020             :     {
    6021          14 :         WindowClause *wc = (WindowClause *) lfirst(l);
    6022             : 
    6023          14 :         if (wc->name == NULL)
    6024          14 :             continue;           /* ignore anonymous windows */
    6025             : 
    6026           0 :         if (sep == NULL)
    6027           0 :             appendContextKeyword(context, " WINDOW ",
    6028             :                                  -PRETTYINDENT_STD, PRETTYINDENT_STD, 1);
    6029             :         else
    6030           0 :             appendStringInfoString(buf, sep);

    6485             :              * Because we would ignore implicit type coercions anyway, we
    6486             :              * don't need to be as careful as processIndirection() is about

    6514             :                 }

    6533             :         /*

    6649             : 
    6650             : /*
    6651             :  * Display a Var appropriately.
    6652             :  *
    6653             :  * In some cases (currently only when recursing into an unnamed join)
    6654             :  * the Var's varlevelsup has to be interpreted with respect to a context
    6655             :  * above the current one; levelsup indicates the offset.
    6656             :  *
    6657             :  * If istoplevel is true, the Var is at the top level of a SELECT's
    6658             :  * targetlist, which means we need special treatment of whole-row Vars.
    6659             :  * Instead of the normal "tab.*", we'll print "tab.*::typename", which is a
    6660             :  * dirty hack to prevent "tab.*" from being expanded into multiple columns.
    6661             :  * (The parser will strip the useless coercion, so no inefficiency is added in
    6662             :  * dump and reload.)  We used to print just "tab" in such cases, but that is
    6663             :  * ambiguous and will yield the wrong result if "tab" is also a plain column
    6664             :  * name in the query.
    6665             :  *
    6666             :  * Returns the attname of the Var, or NULL if the Var has no attname (because
    6667             :  * it is a whole-row Var or a subplan output reference).
    6668             :  */
    6669             : static char *
    6670       24948 : get_variable(Var *var, int levelsup, bool istoplevel, deparse_context *context)
    6671             : {

    6679             :     char       *attname;

    6689             :     /*

    6692             :      * down into the subplans, or INDEX_VAR, which is resolved similarly. Also

    6749             :     /*
    6750             :      * If it's an unnamed join, look at the expansion of the alias variable.

    6919             : 
    6920             : /*
    6921             :  * Get the name of a field of an expression of composite type.  The
    6922             :  * expression is usually a Var, but we handle other cases too.
    6923             :  *
    6924             :  * levelsup is an extra offset to interpret the Var's varlevelsup correctly.
    6925             :  *
    6926             :  * This is fairly straightforward when the expression has a named composite
    6927             :  * type; we need only look up the type in the catalogs.  However, the type
    6928             :  * could also be RECORD.  Since no actual table or view column is allowed to
    6929             :  * have type RECORD, a Var of type RECORD must refer to a JOIN or FUNCTION RTE
    6930             :  * or to a subquery output.  We drill down to find the ultimate defining
    6931             :  * expression and attempt to infer the field name from it.  We ereport if we
    6932             :  * can't determine the name.
    6933             :  *
    6934             :  * Similarly, a PARAM of type RECORD has to refer to some expression of
    6935             :  * a determinable composite type.
    6936             :  */
    6937             : static const char *
    6938          36 : get_name_for_var_field(Var *var, int fieldno,
    6939             :                        int levelsup, deparse_context *context)
    6940             : {
    6941             :     RangeTblEntry *rte;
    6942             :     AttrNumber  attnum;
    6943             :     int         netlevelsup;
    6944             :     deparse_namespace *dpns;
    6945             :     TupleDesc   tupleDesc;
    6946             :     Node       *expr;
    6947             : 
    6948             :     /*
    6949             :      * If it's a RowExpr that was expanded from a whole-row Var, use the
    6950             :      * column names attached to it.
    6951             :      */
    6952          36 :     if (IsA(var, RowExpr))
    6953             :     {
    6954           0 :         RowExpr    *r = (RowExpr *) var;
    6955             : 
    6956           0 :         if (fieldno > 0 && fieldno <= list_length(r->colnames))
    6957           0 :             return strVal(list_nth(r->colnames, fieldno - 1));
    6958             :     }
    6959             : 
    6960             :     /*
    6961             :      * If it's a Param of type RECORD, try to find what the Param refers to.
    6962             :      */
    6963          36 :     if (IsA(var, Param))
    6964             :     {
    6965           4 :         Param      *param = (Param *) var;
    6966             :         ListCell   *ancestor_cell;
    6967             : 
    6968           4 :         expr = find_param_referent(param, context, &dpns, &ancestor_cell);
    6969           4 :         if (expr)
    6970             :         {
    6971             :             /* Found a match, so recurse to decipher the field name */
    6972             :             deparse_namespace save_dpns;
    6973             :             const char *result;
    6974             : 
    6975           4 :             push_ancestor_plan(dpns, ancestor_cell, &save_dpns);
    6976           4 :             result = get_name_for_var_field((Var *) expr, fieldno,
    6977             :                                             0, context);
    6978           4 :             pop_ancestor_plan(dpns, &save_dpns);
    6979           4 :             return result;
    6980             :         }
    6981             :     }
    6982             : 
    6983             :     /*
    6984             :      * If it's a Var of type RECORD, we have to find what the Var refers to;
    6985             :      * if not, we can use get_expr_result_tupdesc().
    6986             :      */
    6987          48 :     if (!IsA(var, Var) ||
    6988          16 :         var->vartype != RECORDOID)
    6989             :     {
    6990          32 :         tupleDesc = get_expr_result_tupdesc((Node *) var, false);
    6991             :         /* Got the tupdesc, so we can extract the field name */
    6992          32 :         Assert(fieldno >= 1 && fieldno <= tupleDesc->natts);
    6993          32 :         return NameStr(TupleDescAttr(tupleDesc, fieldno - 1)->attname);
    6994             :     }
    6995             : 
    6996             :     /* Find appropriate nesting depth */
    6997           0 :     netlevelsup = var->varlevelsup + levelsup;
    6998           0 :     if (netlevelsup >= list_length(context->namespaces))
    6999           0 :         elog(ERROR, "bogus varlevelsup: %d offset %d",
    7000             :              var->varlevelsup, levelsup);
    7001           0 :     dpns = (deparse_namespace *) list_nth(context->namespaces,
    7002             :                                           netlevelsup);
    7003             : 
    7004             :     /*
    7005             :      * Try to find the relevant RTE in this rtable.  In a plan tree, it's
    7006             :      * likely that varno is OUTER_VAR or INNER_VAR, in which case we must dig
    7007             :      * down into the subplans, or INDEX_VAR, which is resolved similarly.
    7008             :      */
    7009           0 :     if (var->varno >= 1 && var->varno <= list_length(dpns->rtable))

    7302             : /*
    7303             :  * Try to find the referenced expression for a PARAM_EXEC Param that might
    7304             :  * reference a parameter supplied by an upper NestLoop or SubPlan plan node.
    7305             :  *
    7306             :  * If successful, return the expression and set *dpns_p and *ancestor_cell_p
    7307             :  * appropriately for calling push_ancestor_plan().  If no referent can be
    7308             :  * found, return NULL.
    7309             :  */
    7310             : static Node *
    7311        1244 : find_param_referent(Param *param, deparse_context *context,
    7312             :                     deparse_namespace **dpns_p, ListCell **ancestor_cell_p)
    7313             : {
    7314             :     /* Initialize output parameters to prevent compiler warnings */

    7318             :     /*

    7321             :      * current expression's PlanState.

    7324             :     {
    7325             :         deparse_namespace *dpns;

    7334        1926 :         foreach(lc, dpns->ancestors)

    7490             : /*
    7491             :  * get_simple_binary_op_name

    7493             :  * helper function for isSimpleNode

    7496             : static const char *

    7514             : 
    7515             : 
    7516             : /*
    7517             :  * isSimpleNode - check if given node is simple (doesn't need parenthesizing)
    7518             :  *
    7519             :  *  true   : simple in the context of parent node's type
    7520             :  *  false  : not simple
    7521             :  */
    7522             : static bool
    7523         910 : isSimpleNode(Node *node, Node *parentNode, int prettyFlags)
    7524             : {
    7525         910 :     if (!node)
    7526           0 :         return false;
    7527             : 
    7528         910 :     switch (nodeTag(node))

    7729             : 
    7730             : /*
    7731             :  * appendContextKeyword - append a keyword to buffer
    7732             :  *
    7733             :  * If prettyPrint is enabled, perform a line break, and adjust indentation.
    7734             :  * Otherwise, just append the keyword.
    7735             :  */
    7736             : static void
    7737        3976 : appendContextKeyword(deparse_context *context, const char *str,
    7738             :                      int indentBefore, int indentAfter, int indentPlus)
    7739             : {
    7740        3976 :     StringInfo  buf = context->buf;
    7741             : 
    7742        3976 :     if (PRETTY_INDENT(context))
    7743             :     {
    7744             :         int         indentAmount;
    7745             : 
    7746        3944 :         context->indentLevel += indentBefore;
    7747             : 
    7748             :         /* remove any trailing spaces currently in the buffer ... */
    7749        3944 :         removeStringInfoSpaces(buf);
    7750             :         /* ... then add a newline and some spaces */
    7751        3944 :         appendStringInfoChar(buf, '\n');
    7752             : 
    7753        3944 :         if (context->indentLevel < PRETTYINDENT_LIMIT)
    7754        3944 :             indentAmount = Max(context->indentLevel, 0) + indentPlus;
    7755             :         else
    7756             :         {
    7757             :             /*
    7758             :              * If we're indented more than PRETTYINDENT_LIMIT characters, try
    7759             :              * to conserve horizontal space by reducing the per-level
    7760             :              * indentation.  For best results the scale factor here should
    7761             :              * divide all the indent amounts that get added to indentLevel
    7762             :              * (PRETTYINDENT_STD, etc).  It's important that the indentation
    7763             :              * not grow unboundedly, else deeply-nested trees use O(N^2)
    7764             :              * whitespace; so we also wrap modulo PRETTYINDENT_LIMIT.
    7765             :              */
    7766           0 :             indentAmount = PRETTYINDENT_LIMIT +
    7767           0 :                 (context->indentLevel - PRETTYINDENT_LIMIT) /
    7768             :                 (PRETTYINDENT_STD / 2);
    7769           0 :             indentAmount %= PRETTYINDENT_LIMIT;
    7770             :             /* scale/wrap logic affects indentLevel, but not indentPlus */
    7771           0 :             indentAmount += indentPlus;
    7772             :         }
    7773        3944 :         appendStringInfoSpaces(buf, indentAmount);
    7774             : 
    7775        3944 :         appendStringInfoString(buf, str);
    7776             : 
    7777        3944 :         context->indentLevel += indentAfter;
    7778        3944 :         if (context->indentLevel < 0)
    7779           0 :             context->indentLevel = 0;
    7780             :     }
    7781             :     else
    7782          32 :         appendStringInfoString(buf, str);
    7783        3976 : }
    7784             : 
    7785             : /*
    7786             :  * removeStringInfoSpaces - delete trailing spaces from a buffer.
    7787             :  *
    7788             :  * Possibly this should move to stringinfo.c at some point.
    7789             :  */
    7790             : static void
    7791        3992 : removeStringInfoSpaces(StringInfo str)
    7792             : {
    7793       10312 :     while (str->len > 0 && str->data[str->len - 1] == ' ')
    7794        2328 :         str->data[--(str->len)] = '\0';
    7795        3992 : }
    7796             : 
    7797             : 
    7798             : /*
    7799             :  * get_rule_expr_paren  - deparse expr using get_rule_expr,
    7800             :  * embracing the string with parentheses if necessary for prettyPrint.
    7801             :  *
    7802             :  * Never embrace if prettyFlags=0, because it's done in the calling node.
    7803             :  *
    7804             :  * Any node that does *not* embrace its argument node by sql syntax (with
    7805             :  * parentheses, non-operator keywords like CASE/WHEN/ON, or comma etc) should
    7806             :  * use get_rule_expr_paren instead of get_rule_expr so parentheses can be
    7807             :  * added.
    7808             :  */
    7809             : static void
    7810       24638 : get_rule_expr_paren(Node *node, deparse_context *context,
    7811             :                     bool showimplicit, Node *parentNode)
    7812             : {
    7813             :     bool        need_paren;
    7814             : 
    7815       25546 :     need_paren = PRETTY_PAREN(context) &&
    7816         908 :         !isSimpleNode(node, parentNode, context->prettyFlags);
    7817             : 
    7818       24638 :     if (need_paren)
    7819          10 :         appendStringInfoChar(context->buf, '(');
    7820             : 
    7821       24638 :     get_rule_expr(node, context, showimplicit);
    7822             : 
    7823       24638 :     if (need_paren)
    7824          10 :         appendStringInfoChar(context->buf, ')');
    7825       24638 : }
    7826             : 
    7827             : 
    7828             : /* ----------
    7829             :  * get_rule_expr            - Parse back an expression
    7830             :  *
    7831             :  * Note: showimplicit determines whether we display any implicit cast that
    7832             :  * is present at the top of the expression tree.  It is a passed argument,
    7833             :  * not a field of the context struct, because we change the value as we
    7834             :  * recurse down into the expression.  In general we suppress implicit casts
    7835             :  * when the result type is known with certainty (eg, the arguments of an
    7836             :  * OR must be boolean).  We display implicit casts for arguments of functions
    7837             :  * and operators, since this is needed to be certain that the same function
    7838             :  * or operator will be chosen when the expression is re-parsed.
    7839             :  * ----------
    7840             :  */
    7841             : static void
    7842       48014 : get_rule_expr(Node *node, deparse_context *context,
    7843             :               bool showimplicit)
    7844             : {
    7845       48014 :     StringInfo  buf = context->buf;
    7846             : 
    7847       48014 :     if (node == NULL)
    7848       48022 :         return;
    7849             : 
    7850             :     /* Guard against excessively long or deeply-nested queries */
    7851       48006 :     CHECK_FOR_INTERRUPTS();
    7852       48006 :     check_stack_depth();
    7853             : 
    7854             :     /*
    7855             :      * Each level of get_rule_expr must emit an indivisible term
    7856             :      * (parenthesized if necessary) to ensure result is reparsed into the same
    7857             :      * expression tree.  The only exception is that when the input is a List,
    7858             :      * we emit the component items comma-separated with no surrounding
    7859             :      * decoration; this is convenient for most callers.
    7860             :      */
    7861       48006 :     switch (nodeTag(node))
    7862             :     {
    7863             :         case T_Var:
    7864       21754 :             (void) get_variable((Var *) node, 0, false, context);

    7869        8964 :             break;

    7873        1240 :             break;

    8017         176 :                                  expr->useOr ? "ANY" : "ALL");
    8018         176 :                 get_rule_expr_paren(arg2, context, true, node);
    8019             : 
    8020             :                 /*
    8021             :                  * There's inherent ambiguity in "x op ANY/ALL (y)" when y is
    8022             :                  * a bare sub-SELECT.  Since we're here, the sub-SELECT must
    8023             :                  * be meant as a scalar sub-SELECT yielding an array value to
    8024             :                  * be used in ScalarArrayOpExpr; but the grammar will
    8025             :                  * preferentially interpret such a construct as an ANY/ALL
    8026             :                  * SubLink.  To prevent misparsing the output that way, insert
    8027             :                  * a dummy coercion (which will be stripped by parse analysis,
    8028             :                  * so no inefficiency is added in dump and reload).  This is
    8029             :                  * indeed most likely what the user wrote to get the construct
    8030             :                  * accepted in the first place.
    8031             :                  */
    8032         178 :                 if (IsA(arg2, SubLink) &&

    8035             :                                      format_type_with_typemod(exprType(arg2),
    8036             :                                                               exprTypmod(arg2)));
    8037         176 :                 appendStringInfoChar(buf, ')');
    8038         176 :                 if (!PRETTY_PAREN(context))
    8039         172 :                     appendStringInfoChar(buf, ')');

    8042             :

    8044             :             {
    8045        1738 :                 BoolExpr   *expr = (BoolExpr *) node;
    8046        1738 :                 Node       *first_arg = linitial(expr->args);
    8047        1738 :                 ListCell   *arg = list_second_cell(expr->args);

    8055             :                                             false, node);
    8056        4674 :                         while (arg)

    8092             : 
    8093             :                     default:
    8094           0 :                         elog(ERROR, "unrecognized boolop: %d",
    8095             :                              (int) expr->boolop);

    8097             :             }

    8104             :         case T_SubPlan:
    8105             :             {
    8106          54 :                 SubPlan    *subplan = (SubPlan *) node;
    8107             :

    8109             :                  * We cannot see an already-planned subplan in rule deparsing,
    8110             :                  * only while EXPLAINing a query plan.  We don't try to
    8111             :                  * reconstruct the original SQL, just reference the subplan
    8112             :                  * that appears elsewhere in EXPLAIN's result.

    8169             :                                                    0, context);

    8171             :             }
    8172          32 :             break;
    8173             : 
    8174             :         case T_FieldStore:
    8175             :             {
    8176           2 :                 FieldStore *fstore = (FieldStore *) node;
    8177             :                 bool        need_parens;
    8178             : 
    8179             :                 /*
    8180             :                  * There is no good way to represent a FieldStore as real SQL,
    8181             :                  * so decompilation of INSERT or UPDATE statements should
    8182             :                  * always use processIndirection as part of the
    8183             :                  * statement-level syntax.  We should only get here when
    8184             :                  * EXPLAIN tries to print the targetlist of a plan resulting
    8185             :                  * from such a statement.  The plan case is even harder than
    8186             :                  * ordinary rules would be, because the planner tries to
    8187             :                  * collapse multiple assignments to the same field or subfield
    8188             :                  * into one FieldStore; so we can see a list of target fields
    8189             :                  * not just one, and the arguments could be FieldStores
    8190             :                  * themselves.  We don't bother to try to print the target
    8191             :                  * field names; we just print the source arguments, with a
    8192             :                  * ROW() around them if there's more than one.  This isn't
    8193             :                  * terribly complete, but it's probably good enough for
    8194             :                  * EXPLAIN's purposes; especially since anything more would be
    8195             :                  * either hopelessly confusing or an even poorer
    8196             :                  * representation of what the plan is actually doing.
    8197             :                  */
    8198           2 :                 need_parens = (list_length(fstore->newvals) != 1);
    8199           2 :                 if (need_parens)
    8200           2 :                     appendStringInfoString(buf, "ROW(");
    8201           2 :                 get_rule_expr((Node *) fstore->newvals, context, showimplicit);
    8202           2 :                 if (need_parens)
    8203           2 :                     appendStringInfoChar(buf, ')');
    8204             :             }
    8205           2 :             break;

    8325             :                          * The parser should have produced WHEN clauses of the
    8326             :                          * form "CaseTestExpr = RHS", possibly with an
    8327             :                          * implicit coercion inserted above the CaseTestExpr.
    8328             :                          * For accurate decompilation of rules it's essential
    8329             :                          * that we show just the RHS.  However in an
    8330             :                          * expression that's been through the optimizer, the
    8331             :                          * WHEN clause could be almost anything (since the
    8332             :                          * equality operator could have been expanded into an
    8333             :                          * inline function).  If we don't recognize the form
    8334             :                          * of the WHEN clause, just punt and display it as-is.

    9024             : 
    9025             : /*
    9026             :  * get_rule_expr_toplevel       - Parse back a toplevel expression
    9027             :  *
    9028             :  * Same as get_rule_expr(), except that if the expr is just a Var, we pass
    9029             :  * istoplevel = true not false to get_variable().  This causes whole-row Vars
    9030             :  * to get printed with decoration that will prevent expansion of "*".
    9031             :  * We need to use this in contexts such as ROW() and VALUES(), where the
    9032             :  * parser would expand "foo.*" appearing at top level.  (In principle we'd
    9033             :  * use this in get_target_list() too, but that has additional worries about
    9034             :  * whether to print AS, so it needs to invoke get_variable() directly anyway.)
    9035             :  */
    9036             : static void
    9037         370 : get_rule_expr_toplevel(Node *node, deparse_context *context,
    9038             :                        bool showimplicit)
    9039             : {
    9040         370 :     if (node && IsA(node, Var))
    9041          56 :         (void) get_variable((Var *) node, 0, true, context);
    9042             :     else
    9043         314 :         get_rule_expr(node, context, showimplicit);
    9044         370 : }
    9045             : 
    9046             : /*
    9047             :  * get_rule_expr_funccall       - Parse back a function-call expression
    9048             :  *
    9049             :  * Same as get_rule_expr(), except that we guarantee that the output will
    9050             :  * look like a function call, or like one of the things the grammar treats as
    9051             :  * equivalent to a function call (see the func_expr_windowless production).
    9052             :  * This is needed in places where the grammar uses func_expr_windowless and
    9053             :  * you can't substitute a parenthesized a_expr.  If what we have isn't going
    9054             :  * to look like a function call, wrap it in a dummy CAST() expression, which
    9055             :  * will satisfy the grammar --- and, indeed, is likely what the user wrote to
    9056             :  * produce such a thing.
    9057             :  */
    9058             : static void
    9059         114 : get_rule_expr_funccall(Node *node, deparse_context *context,
    9060             :                        bool showimplicit)
    9061             : {
    9062         114 :     if (looks_like_function(node))
    9063         110 :         get_rule_expr(node, context, showimplicit);
    9064             :     else
    9065             :     {
    9066           4 :         StringInfo  buf = context->buf;
    9067             : 
    9068           4 :         appendStringInfoString(buf, "CAST(");
    9069             :         /* no point in showing any top-level implicit cast */
    9070           4 :         get_rule_expr(node, context, false);
    9071           4 :         appendStringInfo(buf, " AS %s)",
    9072             :                          format_type_with_typemod(exprType(node),
    9073             :                                                   exprTypmod(node)));
    9074             :     }
    9075         114 : }
    9076             : 
    9077             : /*
    9078             :  * Helper function to identify node types that satisfy func_expr_windowless.
    9079             :  * If in doubt, "false" is always a safe answer.
    9080             :  */
    9081             : static bool
    9082         226 : looks_like_function(Node *node)
    9083             : {
    9084         226 :     if (node == NULL)
    9085           0 :         return false;           /* probably shouldn't happen */
    9086         226 :     switch (nodeTag(node))
    9087             :     {
    9088             :         case T_FuncExpr:

    9098             :         default:
    9099          92 :             break;

    9251             : /*
    9252             :  * get_agg_expr         - Parse back an Aggref node
    9253             :  */
    9254             : static void
    9255         430 : get_agg_expr(Aggref *aggref, deparse_context *context,
    9256             :              Aggref *original_aggref)
    9257             : {
    9258         430 :     StringInfo  buf = context->buf;
    9259             :     Oid         argtypes[FUNC_MAX_ARGS];

    9261             :     bool        use_variadic;

    9263             :     /*
    9264             :      * For a combining aggregate, we look up and deparse the corresponding
    9265             :      * partial aggregate instead.  This is necessary because our input
    9266             :      * argument list has been replaced; the new argument list always has just

    9268             :      * transition states to combine.

    9447             : /* ----------
    9448             :  * get_coercion_expr
    9449             :  *
    9450             :  *  Make a string representation of a value coerced to a specific type
    9451             :  * ----------
    9452             :  */
    9453             : static void
    9454         822 : get_coercion_expr(Node *arg, deparse_context *context,
    9455             :                   Oid resulttype, int32 resulttypmod,
    9456             :                   Node *parentNode)
    9457             : {
    9458         822 :     StringInfo  buf = context->buf;
    9459             : 
    9460             :     /*
    9461             :      * Since parse_coerce.c doesn't immediately collapse application of
    9462             :      * length-coercion functions to constants, what we'll typically see in
    9463             :      * such cases is a Const with typmod -1 and a length-coercion function
    9464             :      * right above it.  Avoid generating redundant output. However, beware of
    9465             :      * suppressing casts when the user actually wrote something like
    9466             :      * 'foo'::text::char(3).
    9467             :      *
    9468             :      * Note: it might seem that we are missing the possibility of needing to
    9469             :      * print a COLLATE clause for such a Const.  However, a Const could only
    9470             :      * have nondefault collation in a post-constant-folding tree, in which the
    9471             :      * length coercion would have been folded too.  See also the special
    9472             :      * handling of CollateExpr in coerce_to_target_type(): any collation
    9473             :      * marking will be above the coercion node, not below it.
    9474             :      */
    9475         922 :     if (arg && IsA(arg, Const) &&
    9476         108 :         ((Const *) arg)->consttype == resulttype &&
    9477           8 :         ((Const *) arg)->consttypmod == -1)
    9478             :     {
    9479             :         /* Show the constant without normal ::typename decoration */
    9480           8 :         get_const_expr((Const *) arg, context, -1);
    9481             :     }
    9482             :     else
    9483             :     {
    9484         814 :         if (!PRETTY_PAREN(context))
    9485         736 :             appendStringInfoChar(buf, '(');
    9486         814 :         get_rule_expr_paren(arg, context, false, parentNode);
    9487         814 :         if (!PRETTY_PAREN(context))
    9488         736 :             appendStringInfoChar(buf, ')');
    9489             :     }
    9490             : 
    9491             :     /*
    9492             :      * Never emit resulttype(arg) functional notation. A pg_proc entry could
    9493             :      * take precedence, and a resulttype in pg_temp would require schema
    9494             :      * qualification that format_type_with_typemod() would usually omit. We've
    9495             :      * standardized on arg::resulttype, but CAST(arg AS resulttype) notation
    9496             :      * would work fine.
    9497             :      */
    9498         822 :     appendStringInfo(buf, "::%s",
    9499             :                      format_type_with_typemod(resulttype, resulttypmod));
    9500         822 : }
    9501             : 
    9502             : /* ----------
    9503             :  * get_const_expr
    9504             :  *
    9505             :  *  Make a string representation of a Const
    9506             :  *
    9507             :  * showtype can be -1 to never show "::typename" decoration, or +1 to always
    9508             :  * show it, or 0 to show it only if the constant wouldn't be assumed to be
    9509             :  * the right type by default.
    9510             :  *
    9511             :  * If the Const's collation isn't default for its type, show that too.
    9512             :  * We mustn't do this when showtype is -1 (since that means the caller will
    9513             :  * print "::typename", and we can't put a COLLATE clause in between).  It's
    9514             :  * caller's responsibility that collation isn't missed in such cases.
    9515             :  * ----------
    9516             :  */
    9517             : static void
    9518        9536 : get_const_expr(Const *constval, deparse_context *context, int showtype)
    9519             : {
    9520        9536 :     StringInfo  buf = context->buf;
    9521             :     Oid         typoutput;
    9522             :     bool        typIsVarlena;
    9523             :     char       *extval;
    9524        9536 :     bool        needlabel = false;
    9525             : 
    9526        9536 :     if (constval->constisnull)
    9527             :     {
    9528             :         /*
    9529             :          * Always label the type of a NULL constant to prevent misdecisions
    9530             :          * about type when reparsing.
    9531             :          */
    9532         136 :         appendStringInfoString(buf, "NULL");
    9533         136 :         if (showtype >= 0)
    9534             :         {
    9535         128 :             appendStringInfo(buf, "::%s",
    9536             :                              format_type_with_typemod(constval->consttype,
    9537             :                                                       constval->consttypmod));
    9538         128 :             get_const_collation(constval, context);
    9539             :         }
    9540         836 :         return;
    9541             :     }
    9542             : 
    9543        9400 :     getTypeOutputInfo(constval->consttype,
    9544             :                       &typoutput, &typIsVarlena);
    9545             : 
    9546        9400 :     extval = OidOutputFunctionCall(typoutput, constval->constvalue);
    9547             : 
    9548        9400 :     switch (constval->consttype)
    9549             :     {
    9550             :         case INT4OID:
    9551             : 
    9552             :             /*
    9553             :              * INT4 can be printed without any decoration, unless it is
    9554             :              * negative; in that case print it as '-nnn'::integer to ensure
    9555             :              * that the output will re-parse as a constant, not as a constant
    9556             :              * plus operator.  In most cases we could get away with printing
    9557             :              * (-nnn) instead, because of the way that gram.y handles negative
    9558             :              * literals; but that doesn't work for INT_MIN, and it doesn't
    9559             :              * seem that much prettier anyway.
    9560             :              */
    9561        5396 :             if (extval[0] != '-')
    9562        5364 :                 appendStringInfoString(buf, extval);
    9563             :             else
    9564             :             {
    9565          32 :                 appendStringInfo(buf, "'%s'", extval);
    9566          32 :                 needlabel = true;   /* we must attach a cast */
    9567             :             }
    9568        5396 :             break;
    9569             : 
    9570             :         case NUMERICOID:
    9571             : 
    9572             :             /*
    9573             :              * NUMERIC can be printed without quotes if it looks like a float
    9574             :              * constant (not an integer, and not Infinity or NaN) and doesn't
    9575             :              * have a leading sign (for the same reason as for INT4).
    9576             :              */
    9577         396 :             if (isdigit((unsigned char) extval[0]) &&
    9578         198 :                 strcspn(extval, "eE.") != strlen(extval))
    9579             :             {
    9580          66 :                 appendStringInfoString(buf, extval);
    9581             :             }
    9582             :             else
    9583             :             {
    9584         132 :                 appendStringInfo(buf, "'%s'", extval);
    9585         132 :                 needlabel = true;   /* we must attach a cast */
    9586             :             }
    9587         198 :             break;
    9588             : 
    9589             :         case BOOLOID:
    9590         128 :             if (strcmp(extval, "t") == 0)
    9591          22 :                 appendStringInfoString(buf, "true");
    9592             :             else
    9593         106 :                 appendStringInfoString(buf, "false");
    9594         128 :             break;
    9595             : 
    9596             :         default:
    9597        3678 :             simple_quote_literal(buf, extval);
    9598        3678 :             break;

    9916             : /* ----------
    9917             :  * get_from_clause          - Parse back a FROM clause
    9918             :  *
    9919             :  * "prefix" is the keyword that denotes the start of the list of FROM
    9920             :  * elements. It is FROM when used to parse back SELECT and UPDATE, but
    9921             :  * is USING when parsing back DELETE.
    9922             :  * ----------
    9923             :  */
    9924             : static void
    9925         656 : get_from_clause(Query *query, const char *prefix, deparse_context *context)
    9926             : {
    9927         656 :     StringInfo  buf = context->buf;

   10018             : static void
   10019        1258 : get_from_clause_item(Node *jtnode, Query *query, deparse_context *context)
   10020             : {
   10021        1258 :     StringInfo  buf = context->buf;
   10022        1258 :     deparse_namespace *dpns = (deparse_namespace *) linitial(context->namespaces);
   10023             : 
   10024        1258 :     if (IsA(jtnode, RangeTblRef))
   10025             :     {
   10026         962 :         int         varno = ((RangeTblRef *) jtnode)->rtindex;
   10027         962 :         RangeTblEntry *rte = rt_fetch(varno, query->rtable);
   10028         962 :         char       *refname = get_rtable_name(varno, context);
   10029         962 :         deparse_columns *colinfo = deparse_columns_fetch(varno, dpns);
   10030         962 :         RangeTblFunction *rtfunc1 = NULL;
   10031             :         bool        printalias;
   10032             : 
   10033         962 :         if (rte->lateral)
   10034           8 :             appendStringInfoString(buf, "LATERAL ");
   10035             : 
   10036             :         /* Print the FROM item proper */
   10037         962 :         switch (rte->rtekind)
   10038             :         {
   10039             :             case RTE_RELATION:
   10040             :                 /* Normal relation RTE */
   10041        1576 :                 appendStringInfo(buf, "%s%s",
   10042         788 :                                  only_marker(rte),
   10043             :                                  generate_relation_name(rte->relid,
   10044             :                                                         context->namespaces));
   10045         788 :                 break;
   10046             :             case RTE_SUBQUERY:
   10047             :                 /* Subquery RTE */
   10048          48 :                 appendStringInfoChar(buf, '(');
   10049          48 :                 get_query_def(rte->subquery, buf, context->namespaces, NULL,
   10050             :                               context->prettyFlags, context->wrapColumn,
   10051             :                               context->indentLevel);
   10052          48 :                 appendStringInfoChar(buf, ')');
   10053          48 :                 break;
   10054             :             case RTE_FUNCTION:
   10055             :                 /* Function RTE */
   10056         108 :                 rtfunc1 = (RangeTblFunction *) linitial(rte->functions);
   10057             : 
   10058             :                 /*
   10059             :                  * Omit ROWS FROM() syntax for just one function, unless it
   10060             :                  * has both a coldeflist and WITH ORDINALITY. If it has both,
   10061             :                  * we must use ROWS FROM() syntax to avoid ambiguity about
   10062             :                  * whether the coldeflist includes the ordinality column.
   10063             :                  */
   10064         206 :                 if (list_length(rte->functions) == 1 &&
   10065          98 :                     (rtfunc1->funccolnames == NIL || !rte->funcordinality))
   10066             :                 {
   10067          98 :                     get_rule_expr_funccall(rtfunc1->funcexpr, context, true);
   10068             :                     /* we'll print the coldeflist below, if it has one */
   10069             :                 }
   10070             :                 else
   10071             :                 {
   10072             :                     bool        all_unnest;
   10073             :                     ListCell   *lc;
   10074             : 
   10075             :                     /*
   10076             :                      * If all the function calls in the list are to unnest,
   10077             :                      * and none need a coldeflist, then collapse the list back
   10078             :                      * down to UNNEST(args).  (If we had more than one
   10079             :                      * built-in unnest function, this would get more
   10080             :                      * difficult.)
   10081             :                      *
   10082             :                      * XXX This is pretty ugly, since it makes not-terribly-
   10083             :                      * future-proof assumptions about what the parser would do
   10084             :                      * with the output; but the alternative is to emit our
   10085             :                      * nonstandard ROWS FROM() notation for what might have
   10086             :                      * been a perfectly spec-compliant multi-argument
   10087             :                      * UNNEST().
   10088             :                      */
   10089          10 :                     all_unnest = true;
   10090          26 :                     foreach(lc, rte->functions)
   10091             :                     {
   10092          22 :                         RangeTblFunction *rtfunc = (RangeTblFunction *) lfirst(lc);
   10093             : 
   10094          44 :                         if (!IsA(rtfunc->funcexpr, FuncExpr) ||
   10095          38 :                             ((FuncExpr *) rtfunc->funcexpr)->funcid != F_ARRAY_UNNEST ||
   10096          16 :                             rtfunc->funccolnames != NIL)
   10097             :                         {
   10098           6 :                             all_unnest = false;
   10099           6 :                             break;
   10100             :                         }
   10101             :                     }
   10102             : 
   10103          10 :                     if (all_unnest)
   10104             :                     {
   10105           4 :                         List       *allargs = NIL;
   10106             : 
   10107          16 :                         foreach(lc, rte->functions)
   10108             :                         {
   10109          12 :                             RangeTblFunction *rtfunc = (RangeTblFunction *) lfirst(lc);
   10110          12 :                             List       *args = ((FuncExpr *) rtfunc->funcexpr)->args;
   10111             : 
   10112          12 :                             allargs = list_concat(allargs, args);
   10113             :                         }
   10114             : 
   10115           4 :                         appendStringInfoString(buf, "UNNEST(");
   10116           4 :                         get_rule_expr((Node *) allargs, context, true);
   10117           4 :                         appendStringInfoChar(buf, ')');
   10118             :                     }

   10381             : /*
   10382             :  * get_from_clause_coldeflist - reproduce FROM clause coldeflist
   10383             :  *
   10384             :  * When printing a top-level coldeflist (which is syntactically also the
   10385             :  * relation's column alias list), use column names from colinfo.  But when
   10386             :  * printing a coldeflist embedded inside ROWS FROM(), we prefer to use the
   10387             :  * original coldeflist's names, which are available in rtfunc->funccolnames.
   10388             :  * Pass NULL for colinfo to select the latter behavior.
   10389             :  *
   10390             :  * The coldeflist is appended immediately (no space) to buf.  Caller is
   10391             :  * responsible for ensuring that an alias or AS is present before it.
   10392             :  */

   10520             : /*
   10521             :  * processIndirection - take care of array and subfield assignment
   10522             :  *
   10523             :  * We strip any top-level FieldStore or assignment SubscriptingRef nodes that
   10524             :  * appear in the input, printing them as decoration for the base column
   10525             :  * name (which we assume the caller just printed).  We might also need to
   10526             :  * strip CoerceToDomain nodes, but only ones that appear above assignment
   10527             :  * nodes.
   10528             :  *
   10529             :  * Returns the subexpression that's to be assigned.
   10530             :  */
   10531             : static Node *
   10532         190 : processIndirection(Node *node, deparse_context *context)
   10533             : {
   10534         190 :     StringInfo  buf = context->buf;

   10608             : 
   10609             : static void
   10610          58 : printSubscripts(SubscriptingRef *sbsref, deparse_context *context)
   10611             : {
   10612          58 :     StringInfo  buf = context->buf;
   10613             :     ListCell   *lowlist_item;
   10614             :     ListCell   *uplist_item;
   10615             : 
   10616          58 :     lowlist_item = list_head(sbsref->reflowerindexpr);   /* could be NULL */
   10617         116 :     foreach(uplist_item, sbsref->refupperindexpr)
   10618             :     {
   10619          58 :         appendStringInfoChar(buf, '[');
   10620          58 :         if (lowlist_item)
   10621             :         {
   10622             :             /* If subexpression is NULL, get_rule_expr prints nothing */
   10623           0 :             get_rule_expr((Node *) lfirst(lowlist_item), context, false);
   10624           0 :             appendStringInfoChar(buf, ':');
   10625           0 :             lowlist_item = lnext(sbsref->reflowerindexpr, lowlist_item);
   10626             :         }
   10627             :         /* If subexpression is NULL, get_rule_expr prints nothing */
   10628          58 :         get_rule_expr((Node *) lfirst(uplist_item), context, false);
   10629          58 :         appendStringInfoChar(buf, ']');
   10630             :     }
   10631          58 : }
   10632             : 
   10633             : /*
   10634             :  * quote_identifier         - Quote an identifier only if needed
   10635             :  *
   10636             :  * When quotes are needed, we palloc the required space; slightly
   10637             :  * space-wasteful but well worth it for notational simplicity.
   10638             :  */
   10639             : const char *
   10640      185808 : quote_identifier(const char *ident)
   10641             : {
   10642             :     /*
   10643             :      * Can avoid quoting if ident starts with a lowercase letter or underscore
   10644             :      * and contains only lowercase letters, digits, and underscores, *and* is
   10645             :      * not any SQL keyword.  Otherwise, supply quotes.
   10646             :      */
   10647      185808 :     int         nquotes = 0;
   10648             :     bool        safe;
   10649             :     const char *ptr;
   10650             :     char       *result;
   10651             :     char       *optr;
   10652             : 
   10653             :     /*
   10654             :      * would like to use <ctype.h> macros here, but they might yield unwanted
   10655             :      * locale-specific results...
   10656             :      */
   10657      185808 :     safe = ((ident[0] >= 'a' && ident[0] <= 'z') || ident[0] == '_');
   10658             : 
   10659     1766640 :     for (ptr = ident; *ptr; ptr++)
   10660             :     {
   10661     1580832 :         char        ch = *ptr;
   10662             : 
   10663     1580832 :         if ((ch >= 'a' && ch <= 'z') ||
   10664      316246 :             (ch >= '0' && ch <= '9') ||
   10665             :             (ch == '_'))
   10666             :         {
   10667             :             /* okay */
   10668             :         }
   10669             :         else
   10670             :         {
   10671        3058 :             safe = false;
   10672        3058 :             if (ch == '"')
   10673           2 :                 nquotes++;
   10674             :         }
   10675             :     }
   10676             : 
   10677      185808 :     if (quote_all_identifiers)
   10678           0 :         safe = false;
   10679             : 
   10680      185808 :     if (safe)
   10681             :     {
   10682             :         /*
   10683             :          * Check for keyword.  We quote keywords except for unreserved ones.
   10684             :          * (In some cases we could avoid quoting a col_name or type_func_name
   10685             :          * keyword, but it seems much harder than it's worth to tell that.)
   10686             :          *
   10687             :          * Note: ScanKeywordLookup() does case-insensitive comparison, but
   10688             :          * that's fine, since we already know we have all-lower-case.
   10689             :          */
   10690      185218 :         int         kwnum = ScanKeywordLookup(ident, &ScanKeywords);
   10691             : 
   10692      185218 :         if (kwnum >= 0 && ScanKeywordCategories[kwnum] != UNRESERVED_KEYWORD)
   10693         340 :             safe = false;
   10694             :     }
   10695             : 
   10696      185808 :     if (safe)
   10697      184878 :         return ident;           /* no change needed */

   10699         930 :     result = (char *) palloc(strlen(ident) + nquotes + 2 + 1);

   10701         930 :     optr = result;
   10702         930 :     *optr++ = '"';
   10703        8390 :     for (ptr = ident; *ptr; ptr++)

   10717             : /*
   10718             :  * quote_qualified_identifier   - Quote a possibly-qualified identifier

   10850             : /*
   10851             :  * generate_function_name
   10852             :  *      Compute the name to display for a function specified by OID,
   10853             :  *      given that it is being called with the specified actual arg names and
   10854             :  *      types.  (Those matter because of ambiguous-function resolution rules.)
   10855             :  *
   10856             :  * If we're dealing with a potentially variadic function (in practice, this
   10857             :  * means a FuncExpr or Aggref, not some other way of calling a function), then
   10858             :  * has_variadic must specify whether variadic arguments have been merged,
   10859             :  * and *use_variadic_p will be set to indicate whether to print VARIADIC in
   10860             :  * the output.  For non-FuncExpr cases, has_variadic should be false and
   10861             :  * use_variadic_p can be NULL.
   10862             :  *
   10863             :  * The result includes all necessary quoting and schema-prefixing.
   10864             :  */

   10866        1978 : generate_function_name(Oid funcid, int nargs, List *argnames, Oid *argtypes,

   10896             :     {
   10897           0 :         if (strcmp(proname, "cube") == 0 || strcmp(proname, "rollup") == 0)

   10900             : 
   10901             :     /*
   10902             :      * Determine whether VARIADIC should be printed.  We must do this first
   10903             :      * since it affects the lookup rules in func_get_detail().

   10905             :      * We always print VARIADIC if the function has a merged variadic-array

   10959             : /*
   10960             :  * generate_operator_name
   10961             :  *      Compute the name to display for an operator specified by OID,
   10962             :  *      given that it is being called with the specified actual arg types.
   10963             :  *      (Arg types matter because of ambiguous-operator resolution rules.
   10964             :  *      Pass InvalidOid for unused arg of a unary operator.)
   10965             :  *

   10967             :  * plus the OPERATOR() decoration needed to use a qualified operator name
   10968             :  * in an expression.

   11033             : 
   11034             : /*
   11035             :  * generate_operator_clause --- generate a binary-operator WHERE clause
   11036             :  *
   11037             :  * This is used for internally-generated-and-executed SQL queries, where
   11038             :  * precision is essential and readability is secondary.  The basic
   11039             :  * requirement is to append "leftop op rightop" to buf, where leftop and
   11040             :  * rightop are given as strings and are assumed to yield types leftoptype
   11041             :  * and rightoptype; the operator is identified by OID.  The complexity
   11042             :  * comes from needing to be sure that the parser will select the desired
   11043             :  * operator when the query is parsed.  We always name the operator using
   11044             :  * OPERATOR(schema.op) syntax, so as to avoid search-path uncertainties.
   11045             :  * We have to emit casts too, if either input isn't already the input type
   11046             :  * of the operator; else we are at the mercy of the parser's heuristics for
   11047             :  * ambiguous-operator resolution.  The caller must ensure that leftop and
   11048             :  * rightop are suitable arguments for a cast operation; it's best to insert
   11049             :  * parentheses if they aren't just variables or parameters.
   11050             :  */
   11051             : void
   11052         830 : generate_operator_clause(StringInfo buf,
   11053             :                          const char *leftop, Oid leftoptype,
   11054             :                          Oid opoid,
   11055             :                          const char *rightop, Oid rightoptype)
   11056             : {
   11057             :     HeapTuple   opertup;
   11058             :     Form_pg_operator operform;
   11059             :     char       *oprname;
   11060             :     char       *nspname;
   11061             : 
   11062         830 :     opertup = SearchSysCache1(OPEROID, ObjectIdGetDatum(opoid));
   11063         830 :     if (!HeapTupleIsValid(opertup))
   11064           0 :         elog(ERROR, "cache lookup failed for operator %u", opoid);
   11065         830 :     operform = (Form_pg_operator) GETSTRUCT(opertup);
   11066         830 :     Assert(operform->oprkind == 'b');
   11067         830 :     oprname = NameStr(operform->oprname);
   11068             : 
   11069         830 :     nspname = get_namespace_name(operform->oprnamespace);
   11070             : 
   11071         830 :     appendStringInfoString(buf, leftop);
   11072         830 :     if (leftoptype != operform->oprleft)
   11073          14 :         add_cast_to(buf, operform->oprleft);
   11074         830 :     appendStringInfo(buf, " OPERATOR(%s.", quote_identifier(nspname));
   11075         830 :     appendStringInfoString(buf, oprname);
   11076         830 :     appendStringInfo(buf, ") %s", rightop);
   11077         830 :     if (rightoptype != operform->oprright)
   11078          20 :         add_cast_to(buf, operform->oprright);
   11079             : 
   11080         830 :     ReleaseSysCache(opertup);
   11081         830 : }
   11082             : 
   11083             : /*
   11084             :  * Add a cast specification to buf.  We spell out the type name the hard way,
   11085             :  * intentionally not using format_type_be().  This is to avoid corner cases
   11086             :  * for CHARACTER, BIT, and perhaps other types, where specifying the type
   11087             :  * using SQL-standard syntax results in undesirable data truncation.  By
   11088             :  * doing it this way we can be certain that the cast will have default (-1)
   11089             :  * target typmod.
   11090             :  */
   11091             : static void
   11092          34 : add_cast_to(StringInfo buf, Oid typid)
   11093             : {
   11094             :     HeapTuple   typetup;
   11095             :     Form_pg_type typform;
   11096             :     char       *typname;
   11097             :     char       *nspname;
   11098             : 
   11099          34 :     typetup = SearchSysCache1(TYPEOID, ObjectIdGetDatum(typid));
   11100          34 :     if (!HeapTupleIsValid(typetup))
   11101           0 :         elog(ERROR, "cache lookup failed for type %u", typid);
   11102          34 :     typform = (Form_pg_type) GETSTRUCT(typetup);
   11103             : 
   11104          34 :     typname = NameStr(typform->typname);
   11105          34 :     nspname = get_namespace_name(typform->typnamespace);
   11106             : 
   11107          34 :     appendStringInfo(buf, "::%s.%s",
   11108             :                      quote_identifier(nspname), quote_identifier(typname));
   11109             : 
   11110          34 :     ReleaseSysCache(typetup);
   11111          34 : }
   11112             : 
   11113             : /*
   11114             :  * generate_qualified_type_name
   11115             :  *      Compute the name to display for a type specified by OID
   11116             :  *
   11117             :  * This is different from format_type_be() in that we unconditionally
   11118             :  * schema-qualify the name.  That also means no special syntax for
   11119             :  * SQL-standard type names ... although in current usage, this should
   11120             :  * only get used for domains, so such cases wouldn't occur anyway.
   11121             :  */
   11122             : static char *
   11123           4 : generate_qualified_type_name(Oid typid)
   11124             : {
   11125             :     HeapTuple   tp;
   11126             :     Form_pg_type typtup;
   11127             :     char       *typname;
